status_message:
Many police departments that used to do a 21 gun salute have moved away from it to the 21 bell salute. The thinking is that it's the gunfire is traumatic to the survivors when the officer dies by gunfire. 

One day, I had a conversation with an officer I worked with about how if we get killed on the job, we wanted the 21 gun salute, no bell. That officer was killed when he got ambushed and shot in the head... And they gave him the damn bell.
link_name: Honor Guard Asked To Relocate 21-Gun Salute By Local Police Department

status_message:
Amazing work with one amazing shot. Officer Ronnie Dorrell is a hero.

Parker, Colorado - Parker Police Department has just released a body cam video showing an intense gunfight between Parker Police and a suicidal suspect.

On September 2nd, 2016, gunfire echoed through the small rural town of Parker, Colorado. Douglas County Sheriff's Office requested assistance for a suicidal suspect who had shot and critically injured Douglas County Sheriff's Detective Dan Brite. 

When officers arrived, the deranged suspect was actively shooting at police officers and civilians with an AK-47 rifle. Parker Police Officer Ronnie Dorrell arrived on scene and wasn't about to let the man harm anyone else. 
In the intense video below, you can see Officer Dorrell jump into action as soon as he arrives on scene. Dorrell grabs is AR-15 and sprints towards the gunfire. 

Officer Dorrell sprints from cover to cover until he gets close enough to take a shot. He tells another officer "move, move!", lines up the shot, fires one time, and eliminates the threat completely.
link_name: Parker Police Department Saves The Day

status_message: Project Blue Stripe was started because many of those in law enforcement are unable to project their voice in fear of backlash from their family, friends and/or employer. It is the silent message that the thin blue line represents that gives voice to all of our heroes in blue. With the media's dominating anti-police rhetoric, the simple presentation of the thin blue line lets our heroes know that we love and believe in them. Show your support by lighting a blue porch light or applying blue painters tape to your rear windshield. A small gesture such as this can mean the world.
link_name: Project Blue Life

status_message: We could not be more excited to see our page hit 1,000,000 Likes. This is a milestone we could never have imagined. The amount of support we have received in these trying times has really encouraged us to continue standing by and supporting our men and women in blue. We thank you all for your continued support, spread the word, the good men and women of Law Enforcement are here to stay. We look forward to our future and have a lot of exciting things to come. Thank you and God Bless.

status_message:
Again, because numerous people ask every day who we are and why we exist:

BLUE LIVES MATTER MISSION STATEMENT

Serving and honoring American law enforcement by tirelessly celebrating their lives and contributions to the communities they protect.

ABOUT

Blue Lives Matter is a media company, made up entirely of active and retired law enforcement officers. In today's evolving society, an increasing number of citizens fail to accept responsibility for their actions and attempt to escape the consequences through outward blame. Due to the nature of the profession, law enforcement personnel are seen as easy targets and are consequently bullied by slander, illegitimate complaints, frivolous law suits, and physical threats. The echo of these negative highlights by the media and political figures have only further damaged community relations, which has greatly increased the inherent threat of the profession. We desire to change these wrongs to law enforcement and once again shed positive light on America's heroes to help boost morale and gain society's much needed support.

The goal of Blue Lives Matter is to honor and recognize the actions of law enforcement to strengthen the public support of an understandably naive society.

The members of our Armed Forces (many include law enforcement) have fought the battles overseas to give Americans the opportunity to live freely at home; however, criminals continue to prey on these rights for personal gain. Americans deserve the right to live their lives with the full protection of the laws but must realize that certain sacrifices should not be taken in vain. Law enforcement officers are also deserving citizens of these rights with personal lives, dreams, and families. While these heroes and their families accept an elevated inherent risk for minimal pay, they should not be expected to make such a great sacrifice without due recognition and support. Through strengthened support, law enforcement personnel will be provided a much needed boost in morale and can return full productivity back to the streets resulting in a safer America.

HISTORY

On August 9 2014, Ferguson PD Officer Darren Wilson was doing his job as he stopped Michael Brown, who had just committed a robbery of a local convenience store. Brown attacked Officer Wilson in an aggravated assault. Officer Wilson was forced to defend his life by shooting Brown. In the months that followed, agitators spread outright lies and distortions of the truth about Officer Wilson and all police officers. The media catered to movements such as Black Lives Matter, who's goal was the vilification of law enforcement. Criminals who rioted and victimized innocent citizens were further given legitimacy by the media as "protesters." America watched as criminals destroyed property, and assaulted and murdered innocent people, and they labeled these criminals as victims. Personal responsibility for one's actions went away, replaced by accusations of racism and an unjust government. It seemed that almost every media organization was spreading the absurd message that people were being shot by law enforcement simply because of the color of their skin. Our political leaders pandered to these criminals and helped spread this false narrative, with no thought of the consequences.

On December 20, 2014, NYPD Officer Rafael Ramos and Officer Wenjian Liu were ambushed and murdered by a fanatic who believed the lies of Black Lives Matter, the media, and politicians. While reporting on the murder of these heroes, the media continued to spread the false narrative of Black Lives Matter. Even the big law enforcement media companies, who purport to be all for the police, helped spread misinformation through re-posting articles written with an anti-police bias. This highlighted that these companies weren't run by law enforcement, and they only cared about saving time and money "reporting" the news.

The officers who founded this organization were motivated by the heroic actions of Officer Darren Wilson, and many others, and decided to create this organization in the hopes that it could prevent more officers from being hurt.

link_name: Blue Lives Matter

status_message:
A high school senior wrote this essay which won him first place for a college scholarship. Please read this very well written and accurate essay describing the life of an Officer and his family...

"Having a dad as a police officer has affected our family compared to other non-LEO families. However, it is what we're used to because that's what we've always known.

Having a dad as a cop is knowing that when he says he'll be home by five or six, it could mean after midnight. It means that his week of laundry consists of five black shirts, five pairs of socks, and five pairs of underwear. It means seeing his boots and duty belt on the floor. It's hearing great stories at dinner. It's being completely desensitized to everything and having a dark sense of humor. It's yelling at the media on TV. It's predicting what's going to happen on "COPS" before it happens. It's correcting the falsities in any police show or movie. It's how he always sits at a table so he can face everyone. It's walking in the city and holding his hand but having to switch hands so his gun hand is always free.

It's when you come home feeling sick and he drug tests you not once, but twice. It's having someone who knows how to read body language and talk to people. It's having someone who knows how to drive really well. It's giving him a hug and feeling something under his jacket. It's calling him on the phone and hearing yelling, sirens, or the radio in the background before he quickly hangs up. It's wanting to go to the station and everyone remembers when you were a baby. It's when you're walking with him in the city and he tells you to run and call for help if he tells you to. It's him telling you to take off your seatbelt so you can escape if something happens. It's when you go on a class fieldtrip into the city and for the first time, he insists on going with you to keep you safe.

It's when a neighbor thinks she heard something in her house and he searches it for her. It's having people ask you legal questions and how they can get out of a ticket. It's being called a narc at school because your dad is a cop. It's how he knows the best places to eat in the city and the best routes to avoid traffic. It's learning strong moral values. It's valuing the precious time you have with family. It's having to reschedule birthday and holiday celebrations. It's knowing a full moon means trouble. It's teasing but still appreciating the fire department. It's purposely not living close to his work. It's knowing that he has to deal with some really sad and evil things. It's knowing that when he used to say monsters weren't real, he was lying.

It's loving the sound of sirens. It's feeling safe around guns and knowing how to shoot well. It's wanting to be a cop and his trying to tell you to look at anything else. It's waving to every police car you see. It's when you decide on a college and he suddenly knows an officer in that city. It's knowing things that others aren't allowed to know, yet you can't correct them. You argue for the police whenever somebody criticizes them because they've never heard any of the real stories you know. It's feeling that every officer killed on the news is personal. It's getting the shivers down your spine when you hear the bagpipes play "Amazing Grace." It's praying that he'll make it home safe. It's that your heroes wear Kevlar instead of capes. It's being so proud of your dad for the job he does. It's having that little voice in the back of your head that his car may be replaced with one carrying the chief, captain, and chaplain telling you the news you dread."
 
By Victor M.

Where is my Country?

Where is my country? 
Where can she be?
The one that I was raised to respect and love.
The one that I pledge allegiance to, under the one Christian God above.

Where is my country that my Grandfather would tell me stories about?
The country that is known all throughout.
She is known for her leadership and courage through thick and thin.
She was built and is maintained with heroes that live within.

Where is my country that shows strength and might?
The country that I know never backs down from a fight.
She is respected and looked up to by other countries around the world.
The people that live within her are always willing to help, before other countries can say a word.

But where is my country?
Where can she be?
This is truly the question that baffles me.

As I look around for my country all that I see is hatred, selfishness and greed.
I do not see a united country under God
But a country that is divided and covered in a fog.

But where is my country?
Where can she be?
Is it as simple as she is hiding from me?
Is she kept in one house under lock and key?
Or is she out there somewhere among the people waiting to be seen?

Is she under all of the egg shells that we are forced to walk?
Or is she in the words that we are too afraid to talk?
Is my country in the crowds that walk on top of heroes' graves?
Or in the demonstrations that are full of hate and rage?

Has my country been stolen by those who want it most?
The ones who fear freedom and the one Holy Host.

I look for my country both day and night.
I hope and pray I will find her so everything will be alright.
I look to the left and I look to the right
But I see no leadership in sight.
Who can tell me where my country can be?
Maybe if I look closely I will finally see.

There at last!
I found my country.
I can't believe how I did not see.
My country is in both you and me.

My country is within the people that stand for justice and love.
My country is with people that help others and believe in the one true God above.
My country is strong with the heroes among us.
Those that are willing to sacrifice all that they have
So that we can have safety and peace in our land.
My country can be found in each one of us.
All we have to do is come together and trust.

Trust in the Lord with all your heart.
Make sure that you contribute and do your part.
Our country is not gone but to most it has been lost.
But we cannot forget those that paid the ultimate cost.

Our country can be found. 
We must look within.
We need to turn away from evil and sin.
For we should all love and respect the country that we live in.

-Trooper Vido, Indiana

status_message:
Because we keep getting asked why we exist:

BLUE LIVES MATTER MISSION STATEMENT

Serving and honoring American law enforcement by tirelessly celebrating their lives and contributions to the communities they protect.

ABOUT

Blue Lives Matter is a media company, made up entirely of active and retired law enforcement officers. In today's evolving society, an increasing number of citizens fail to accept responsibility for their actions and attempt to escape the consequences through outward blame. Due to the nature of the profession, law enforcement personnel are seen as easy targets and are consequently bullied by slander, illegitimate complaints, frivolous law suits, and physical threats. The echo of these negative highlights by the media and political figures have only further damaged community relations, which has greatly increased the inherent threat of the profession. We desire to change these wrongs to law enforcement and once again shed positive light on America's heroes to help boost morale and gain society's much needed support.

The goal of Blue Lives Matter is to honor and recognize the actions of law enforcement to strengthen the public support of an understandably naive society.

The members of our Armed Forces (many include law enforcement) have fought the battles overseas to give Americans the opportunity to live freely at home; however, criminals continue to prey on these rights for personal gain. Americans deserve the right to live their lives with the full protection of the laws but must realize that certain sacrifices should not be taken in vain. Law enforcement officers are also deserving citizens of these rights with personal lives, dreams, and families. While these heroes and their families accept an elevated inherent risk for minimal pay, they should not be expected to make such a great sacrifice without due recognition and support. Through strengthened support, law enforcement personnel will be provided a much needed boost in morale and can return full productivity back to the streets resulting in a safer America.

HISTORY

On August 9 2014, Ferguson PD Officer Darren Wilson was doing his job as he stopped Michael Brown, who had just committed a robbery of a local convenience store. Brown attacked Officer Wilson in an aggravated assault. Officer Wilson was forced to defend his life by shooting Brown. In the months that followed, agitators spread outright lies and distortions of the truth about Officer Wilson and all police officers. The media catered to organizations such as Black Lives Matter, who's goal was the vilification of law enforcement. Criminals who rioted and victimized innocent citizens were further given legitimacy by the media as "protesters." America watched as criminals destroyed property, and assaulted and murdered innocent people, and they labeled these criminals as victims. Personal responsibility for one's actions went away, replaced by accusations of racism and an unjust government. It seemed that almost every media organization was spreading the absurd message that people were being shot by law enforcement simply because of the color of their skin. Our political leaders pandered to these criminals and helped spread this false narrative, with no thought of the consequences.

On December 20, 2014, NYPD Officer Rafael Ramos and Officer Wenjian Liu were ambushed and murdered by a fanatic who believed the lies of Black Lives Matter, the media, and politicians. While reporting on the murder of these heroes, the media continued to spread the lies of Black Lives Matter. Even the big law enforcement media companies, who purport to be all for the police, helped spread misinformation through re-posting articles written with an anti-police bias. This highlighted that these companies weren't run by law enforcement, and they only cared about saving time and money "reporting" the news.

The officers who founded this organization were motivated by the heroic actions of Officer Darren Wilson, and many others, and decided to create this organization in the hopes that it could prevent more officers from being hurt.
WATCH: A lowlife thief practically pulls an entire refrigerator worth of meat (the kind you cook...on a grill...get your mind out of the gutter...) out of his pants.

I had one of proudest moments in my life yesterday when I watched the young woman who I've always thought of as "my little girl" graduate with High Honors" from High School.  In reality of course I have no children, but 17 years ago, the fate of Jacky and I collided one cold Vegas night when, as a Las Vegas Metro Police Sergeant, I came upon she and her family moments after she had been shot in the face and not breathing.  Her family was the innocent victim of a gang initiation and several  gang members pulled up to the young family at a traffic light and opened fire, striking one month old Jacky.  In one of the most emotional moments that has replayed in my mind a thousand times, I will never forget the horror of seeing her tiny face ravaged by the bullet choking off her air supply.  But because of God or the Fates or whatever Higher Being determines destiny, I was able to bring her back to this world.  My life has never been the same.  I have watched her grow from a child into the beautiful person that she has become in all ways, but especially within her heart. During my more than thirty years as a cop, i have seen courage in all of its forms. Through the countless surgeries, operations and procedures Jacky has not only endured the pain but conquered it with grace, thanks to her own soul and the love of her family. 

 As I walk the narrowing pathway of this life, I'll remember that moment on a cold,dark Las Vegas street and realize that I had met someone who would become forever, My Hero. 

- Randy Sutton
link_name: Officer celebrates graduation of girl he saved 17 years ago

status_message:
On Friday May 27th, K9 Deputy Howell responded to the wooded area of  SR 26/SR 93 after CCC received a report of two males who were possibly trying to lure a small child into the woods. Upon arrival, Deputy Howell found 3 year old Keagen Robinson, his father Jacob, grandfather Thomas, and his service dog Red all sleeping in a tent in the wooded area adjacent to SR93. The Robinson's originally drove from Henderson, Kentucky, to Foley, Alabama, to attend a family funeral, however, when they arrived, their truck broke down which left them stranded. In an attempt to get back home, the Robinson's hitchhiked from Alabama and wound up in Gainesville on Thursday.
 
Knowing the environment and living conditions were not suitable for most adults, much less a 3 year old child, fervent efforts were made to get the Robinson's out of the woods for the night with the ultimate goal of helping them get back home to Kentucky.
 
To no surprise, Team 1 Days, Team 1 Nights, ASO K9, Detective Gregalot and GPD all stepped up and in less than 4 hours donated nearly $700 to help the Robinson's. Greyhound bus tickets were purchased for the Robinson's and K9 Red. Toiletries and a change of clothes were purchased so the Robinson's could shower at ASO in preparation for the 23 hour bus ride. Detective Gregalot took Keagen and his father to see the Angry Birds movie to pass the time until the Greyhound bus arrived. A Superman backpack was filled with snacks, a coloring book, a blanket, pajamas and a new pair of sandals to keep Keagan pacified for the long ride. Prepaid fast food gift cards were provided so they would have food to eat along the bus route. At 2100 hours tonight (May 27th), the Robinson's and Red all boarded a Greyhound bus from Gainesville headed to Evansville Indiana which would ultimately take them to where they needed to be, home.

status_message:
"New York State Trooper is being praised for helping to save a 12-year-old boy who suffered a heart attack in the pool at the Northwest Family YMCA on Thursday.

According to State Police, Trooper Shaun Smith  a tri-athlete  was swimming at the YMCA when he saw two young boys swimming in one of the lanes.

When Smith began his next lap, he saw one of the boys underwater, and the other swimming down to him.

When the other boy brought his friend to the surface, Smith and the boy brought him to poolside.

Smith administered CPR while a lifeguard grabbed an AED."
link_name: Off-duty cop helps save Baldwinsville boy at YMCA

status_message:
Good to see more citizens stepping up to help. 

NORWICH, Conn. (AP)  Police in Connecticut say they were able to apprehend a suspect they were running after thanks to a passing motorist who saw the foot pursuit and offered an officer a ride.
The Bulletin of Norwich (http://bit.ly/1O6yY6y ) reports that two Norwich officers on Wednesday pulled over a vehicle that was suspected of being involved in an earlier road rage incident.
The driver fled on foot and officers gave chase.
During the pursuit, an unknown citizen driving by offered a ride to one officer, who accepted. The officer was dropped off in front of the suspect and arrested him.

The anonymous driver then left the scene, but police issued a public thank you.
The suspect, meanwhile, faces a charge of driving a motor vehicle while under suspension, and drug offenses.

status_message:
Via the Louisville Metro Police Department: In 1954, a Louisville Police officer was approached by a distraught 12-year-old boy who just learned his brand new bike had been stolen. The frustrated boy told the officer he'd whip the thief if he ever found him. The officer invited the youngster to learn to fight properly by joining the boxing gym where the officer mentored young fighters.

Over the years the officer helped mentor the young fighter as he went on to win six Kentucky Golden Gloves titles, two national Amateur Athletic Union titles, and the heavyweight gold at the 1960 Olympics and became known to millions as "The Greatest." 

Today, we join the world in mourning the passing of Muhammad Ali, and we are grateful for the legacy of Louisville Police Officer Joe E. Martin and his willingness to help a young Cassius Clay in need. 

May we continue to find opportunities to invest in the lives of our youth, and may we see each encounter as an opportunity to influence "The Greatest."

#RememberingAli
#MuhammadAli
#LouisvilleLegend
#Ali
#TheGreatest
#Bluelivesmatter

19 year old Darryl Lewis was wanted by police for stealing a vehicle during a test drive, strong armed robbery and aggravated assault of an elder woman, in which he ran over her legs to flee the scene the day before. In the early morning hours of November 10, 1988 Lewis was spotted by KCKPD. High on PCP, Lewis refused to stop for police and a pursuit ensued. Officer Young and other officers set up a roadblock on the Lewis and Clark viaduct to snag Lewis in traffic. As Officer Young approached Darryl Lewis's vehicle Lewis hit the accelerator and struck officer Young with his car throwing Officer Young into the air, over the vehicle and landing on the concrete head first.

"Late Tuesday night, a couple of members of the Hallsville 2016 senior class allegedly stripped the tires off the police department's reserve Tahoe cruiser and left the SUV on blocks near a high traffic area, near Highway 80 and Farm-to-Market Road 450.

After realizing that this wasn't a random tire theft, but instead a 'harmless' senior prank, Police Chief Paul Montoya took to social media on Wednesday morning. In his video, Chief Montoya held up a photo of the Tahoe on blocks and said, "That's funny, it's an epic prank, I've never seen a prank that well planned out." He continued, "Good job guys. You got us, we're not mad about it. What can you do? you just laugh and say, you got us."
link_name: Police chief: 'Epic' senior prank should be once in a lifetime thing

Early Sunday evening, Tarentino was escorted by dozens of police motorcycles and cruisers. Hundreds of people many with flags, police officers and fire fighters lined Main Street leading up to Morin Funeral Home. This young boy, Camden, is the son of the police officer hugging him in the photo, longtime Auburn Officer Keith Chipman.

The boy had just realized why he was there and that Tarentino, a friend of their family, had been killed. The boy ran to his father, and as he hugged him, Camden pleaded with his father, "Daddy, please don't be a police officer anymore."

RIP Officer Tarentino, the world needs more Heroes like you. 

Image Credit: Worcester Magazine

Thirty years.  The Chief of San Francisco PD who served the department for thirty years has been forced to resign. The incredibly biased city government of San Francisco has forced a Chief who has been on the job for thirty years to resign because of their politically correct desire for a scapegoat and who better than a white Police Chief? 

Sorry folks, but this is the reality. One of the most diverse police agencies in the United States has suffered the slings and arrows of a liberal city government, media, and moronic "activists." There is no possible way for this department to get police work done in a way "acceptable" to these idiots, they decided to fire their Chief. A quick "fix" in their mind.

I have news for the people of San Francisco, the barbarians are at the gate. If you don't allow your police to do their jobs you will be subjugated by criminals and idiots. The most unfortunate reality? Those making the decisions to allow insurrection and criminal anarchy will be safe behind their walls while the majority of hard working people in the city suffer.
 - Randy Sutton

status_message:
The school district in Milwaukee has budgeted almost half a million dollars for BlackLivesMatter although there is no way to tell who the money is going to actually go to!  That's right, the taxpayers are going to pay almost half a million dollars to an anarchist organization who advocate violence against the police and the United States Government.  When I did a little digging I found a "resolution" that states why they citizens should pony up the cash written by someone connected to the school board.  You won't believe what it says but I have printed it below.  Ready?  get out your blood pressure meds:

WHEREAS, The killing of unarmed Black men and women has left young people searching for answers to incredibly complicated and infuriating questions; and

WHEREAS, The extrajudicial killing of Black people in this country has deep roots in the dehumanizing system of white supremacy that once defined Black bodies as property, and persisted in the form of lynchings during the 100 years of Jim Crow. The mob and the whip have been replaced by government sponsored "programs" like COINTELPRO, the war on drugs, mass incarceration, unjust policing and structural policies that maintain racial segregation (redlining, urban renewal and more) that exploit and oppress poor communities. Because these tragedies are not new and have lasting negative consequences for our communities, cities and nation, we need to assert, over and over again, that the lives of Black people matter.  

There you have it folks.  The lies and propaganda being vomited out by those whose true goal is to destroy the fabric of our nation is being accepted by those whose influence touches the most vulnerable people in our country, our children.  This is despicable and insidious.  
-Randy Sutton

Via the Baton Rouge Police Department:

"On the morning of February 13, 2016, Officer Teddy Smith and Officer Sean Garic faced a deadly situation and barely escaped with their lives. After almost three months of internal investigations and independent investigations by the District Attorney's Office both officers were cleared in the shooting death of Calvin Smith. 

After the conclusions of the two separate investigations in car camera video and body camera, video from this incident is able to be released. 

We want to take a moment to post portions of the videos to our Facebook page in an effort to show the public the valor of these two officers under immense pressure while being fired upon by the suspect with a high powered rifle. The full videos along with the District Attorney's findings can be seen at http://www.ebrda.org/ 

This is a situation that no officer ever wants to face but by the grace of GOD and their training they were able to survive this encounter.

status_message:
Somebody pass me the aspirin.  First the Obama administration refuses to use the phrase "Muslim " in any connotation of extremism or terrorism because of their rabid political correctness. Now as Obama and the United States Department of Justice puts the lives of hundreds of thousands of American citizens in danger by their wholesale release of prisoners, they are ramping up the propaganda machine into overdrive.  In what would be comical if it were a Saturday Night Live skit, the DOJ is removing certain words that they find distasteful ( although factual and descriptive) such as "criminal.  Yes, you heard me right, instead of referring to criminals as....well, criminals, the new politcal speak shall hereafter refer to them as "justice involved individuals! Oh yes and felons and convicts?  They will now be known  as "person who committed a crime" or "individual who was incarcerated".
 I feel like I'm in a Fellini movie with some weird alternative reality surrounding me. Violent crime and murder is skyrocketing all over the country ( mostly in cities that are controlled by Democrats), law enforcement is under siege and public confidence in the Justice System is circling the bowl and how does Loretta Lynch, the Attorney General of the United States tackle the issues?  By renaming murderers, thugs, rapists and crooks so that their feelings don't get hurt.  Buckle your belts people, Obama and his minions will do as much damage to this nation as they possibly can till he is out of office. 
 -Randy Sutton

I am just a cop

Actors play me as a hero in movies making millions
Then do interviews calling me an evil thug

Citizens bitch about my speed when seeing me race to a call someplace else
Then complain I took to long when responding to their home

The news media questioned why I used a gun versus TASER last week
This week they question if my TASER is excessive use of force

Network TV shows depict me as the good guy in Prime Time to sell advertising
Network News shows depict me as the enemy during news hour to sell advertising

Lawmakers call for me to have more training at election time
Then slash my budget taking away training money at tax time

Parents call me to "scare" their kids into behaving and following the law
Later they call me to complain I arrested their kids who "never" get in trouble

Neighbors tell me they respect me and could never do my job
In that same conversation, they tell me what I do wrong and how to better do my job

Society elects officials to enact laws for me to enforce
Yet society blames for laws they feel are unfair

Protestors advocate for violence against me
At a protest where I am protecting them from the violence of others

Community members ask me to sacrifice my life in the service of others
They then complain when my funeral procession disrupts traffic

City Hall expects me to give up time with my family to work extra
But City Hall then complains about my overtime earnings

My management asks me to charge into the face of danger and stress
The same management ignores my PTSD or other stress illnesses

I am just a cop

status_message:
Heroes not only to people but furry ones too!

On Sunday, Facebook user Peggy Edwards took to social media to share a touching photo which she captured of a police officer who had just rescued a dog. Edwards uploaded the photo of the barefoot officer, identified as Joe Brazil with Rhode Island's Woonsocket Police Department, along with an explanation of what she witnessed. Edwards wrote, "I wanted to share this picture with everyone I can... 

On Sat. April 30th, a little dog was running free and was frightened by a passing car. It ran into a tunnel that a nearby brook flows through." She added, "She was stuck about 20-25 ft in and was clinging to the side. We tried to help but were afraid of scaring her further in." 

Knowing the the small dog was in distress, a call was made to the Woonsocket Police - Officer Joe Brazil responded and according to Edwards, he "went in without hesitation" and promptly rescued the soggy, scared dog. 

Edwards explained why she wanted to share the touching photograph, "With all the negatives people post and say about police, I thought we should see a positive moment. It may not seem like much to most people but it meant a lot to us and to that scared little dog, it made a world of difference as certain death was at the end of that tunnel. Thank you Officer Brazil...hope the dog is doing well."

status_message: WATCH: Athens, GA body cam footage from an officer involved shooting. Officer approaches a vehicle with two male occupants whom he observed pouring liquor into cups. The backseat passenger steps out of the vehicle whereupon a firearm can be seen in his front right pocket. After multiple commands, to which the suspect does not comply, he then goes to reach for his gun and the officer fires. Despite striking the suspect in the face, and a failed taser deployment, he leads this officer on a 3 minute foot chase. Suspects family is concerned with this officers actions but we say, well done Officer, way to stay in the fight.

Fantastic ruling by the Supreme Court in a case of a Mayor and Police Chief who demoted a Detective because he was seen with a sign of the man running against the Mayor during the election season.. I have long spoken of Administrative Corruption in Law Enforcement.  That is when people in positions of power use that power not for the good of the agency but for their own personal reasons such as animosity, revenge, and political favoritism.  Law Enforcement Officers all over the country face this kind of treatment every day and it is one of the most demoralizing issues facing them.  Police morale is already being crushed because of the current events facing law enforcement, when you ad personal and political interference into a police officers career, you have a recipe for de-policing. This ruling perhaps might make other political and police leaders think twice before interfering in the careers of their officers for personal agendas.  
-Randy Sutton
link_name: U.S. Supreme Court sides with ex-Paterson police officer in free speech case

status_message: The topic of Police Suicide is one of the most difficult conversations to have.  There are so many factors that contribute to these tragic decisions.  Almost every Law Enforcement Officer I know, has been affected in one way or another by the suicide of a fellow officer.  I delved into this topic this week on 'POLICE RADIO, The Voice of American Law Enforcement" on the America Outloud Network.  Go to ITunes and subscribe to America Outloud or to Americaoutloud.com and listen to POLICE RADIO.  There is help for Officers suffering from depression, PTSD, addiction and emotional pain.  I am also personally available to any officer in need.  -Randy Sutton

WATCH: Body camera footage of the tragic death of Hero Sgt Jason Gooding has been released. Gooding and Officer David Davidson were approaching a wanted suspect. They informed him that he was going to be placed under arrest. This man, Phillip Ferry, did not comply. The two Heroes attempted to use a taser to gain control of Ferry...but Ferry fought through the taze and fired a round at Sgt Gooding, which ultimately killed him. Ofc. Davidson returned fire, killing Ferry...

People say we signed up for this, it's just a job, we knew the risk...that is not the case...We signed up to help others, not to die and take lives in the process. Sgt Gooding died a Hero and Officer Davidson, we thank God you are still with us. You are a Hero to us all as well.
Lol

status_message: WATCH: NYPD Heroes take verbal abuse and threats from a disorderly mob. What would you do in their shoes?

Gail J from Richmond, VA wanted to share this story:

"I was shopping at the Golden Eagle convenience story in Gilpin Court when Officer Saunders from the Richmond police department came in for his nightly visit. After a few minutes I noticed a grandmother with her 4 grandchildren come in. The boys were excited to see the Officer & began to huddle around him. The officer spoke with the kids before they went away to grab some chips.
One of the boys found his way back to officer Saunders and gave him a long hug while saying "thank you". It melted my heart. The others also found their way back to him and began to shake hands and expressed how they wanted to be police officers when they grew up.

After a few minutes Officer Saunders left the store & immediately returned with gifts for each child. He gave them police themed matchbox cars & legos. The kids were so thankful & excited for the gifts....especially since they were "police" gifts from a real police officer.
The officer stayed and chatted with the kids a few more minutes before he was called away for duty.

It's nice to see that in the world we live in, there are Officers that still care about the community & the people in it. He didn't have to do what he did, but he truly looked like he was just as excited as the kids were. I could see that the hug he received touched his heart. I saw it in his eyes. He was also kind enough to take a picture with everyone. (I got a copy from the clerk that took the picture)

I've seen Officer Saunders in this store several times & he has always been kind towards everyone he encounters. I am glad that he works in this area and from the looks of things, there are a few others glad as well."

status_message:
"A pair of Chicago police officers are being called heroes after saving the life of a fellow officer.

During a shift change around 10 p.m. Saturday, a 55-year-old officer suddenly collapsed and lost consciousness in the lobby of police headquarters at 35th and Michigan.

Officer Norma Colon, who was reporting for duty, saw the veteran officer collapse and rushed to help him. Her partner, Officer Beata Staszewski, performed CPR on him. Other officers then grabbed a defibrillator and used it on him."
link_name: 2 Chicago police officers save veteran officer's life

status_message:
"Dressed in blue and black, with a badge of armor. He protects and serves and puts his life on the line for the fellow general public. He's one of the finest misunderstood and hated individuals. Hated by some, loved by many. One of the greatest of heroes. He's a police officer. 

He puts his life at risk every single day for the needed protection of others. He is continually on call, and he never knows what will happen the moment he puts on his suit and badge. He knows that his life is always on edge. One breath could soon be none. 

If there were no officers of the law, there would be an outbreak of unneeded chaos and an overtake of evil. The world's population would drop drastically, as people would hurt and kill who whoever they please. The officers of the law do the best they can to provide peace and happiness for us all as a nation together.

He uses his very five senses to the extremity. He sees horrific terror and sadness of other individuals. He has heard the helpless, sheer screams and cries of many. He has smelt the undenying scent of death. He has touched the bones of the lost and tortured. He has tasted the tears of the mourning. 

He puts his blood, sweat, and tears into his profession. He's an officer of peace and love. He loves those who are unloved. He protects those who deny protection. He serves those who can't serve themselves. He gives his life up to those who would take his. He's a peace officer. Loved by many, hated by some. He's a police officer."

Written by Leah Cornell

status_message:
"There's this day every American is waiting for. Some people know it as the American dream, characterized with a lot of money, a big house and a beautiful family. The day when you can finally say "I made it."

Put simply, this day is a lie.

Growing up in a neighborhood of cops and firemen, where a good amount of people are discharged from work with three-quarters of their normal salary, I had the chance to see a lot of people "retire" between 40 and 50 with a steady stream of income. Some of these people became gym teachers at my school, took on security jobs or just retired from work altogether. Of those people who took different paths, I would say the least happy is the person who just sat around collecting paychecks."
link_name: Stop Waiting For The Day When You Can Say "I Made It"

status_message:
Please see the below letter from GiveKits.org. They need help fulfilling requests for all the First Aid kits they want to donate to all the departments who need them. 

"I'm reaching out because I started a campaign called Kits 4 Cops. I'm not LEO; although I did spend about 10 years in the Army on Active Duty 2004-2013 so it's similar in ways.

I'll let the infographic do most of the talking but the main point is that most LEO don't have First Aid Kits. When I found out about this I decided to do something about it- Kits 4 Cops - a program where the community and business can support their local Officers by donating to the program and a First Aid Kit is delivered to the officer or department of their choosing. 

I don't get paid anything to do this. 

I'm just trying to help the over 1 Million Law Enforcement Officers that protect us since statistically they are the first ones to the scene of an accident."

This is a great organization please help if you can.

Please read the below letter. A big supporter and follower of Blue Lives Matter is requesting patches for a student he works with. This student one day wants to be a Police Officer, check it out and help if you can: 

"First off, as an EMT and friend to many LEOs, I love what you're doing. Keep it up!

Next, I also work as a Teacher's Assistant in Nekoosa, WI. I work in a one-to-one capacity with a kindergarten student in the LD/ED Department. This is an exceptional young man who has aspirations of becoming a police officer when he grows up. 

I am trying to implement a reward program with him where if he has a full day with no undesired behaviors, he can receive a police shoulder patch to add to a wall in our room. I currently have patches from all of the Departments in our county, and am now reaching outward to areas farther away.

I was hoping you would be willing to ask your Facebook fan base (a good portion of whom I'm sure are LEOs themselves) to send a shoulder patch to this young man.

The patch can be mailed to:

Humke Elementary School
Attn Ben Holberg, rm 115
500 S Section St
Nekoosa WI 54457

Thank you for your time, and I hope to hear from you soon."

status_message:
Four years ago today, Chief Michael Maloney was killed in the line of duty, eight days from retirement. 

On April 12, 2012, Chief Michael Maloney was requested by members of the New Hampshire Attorney General's Drug Task Force to assist with the execution of a search warrant in Greenland, NH.

They were immediately met with gunfire and four sustained gunshot wounds. As the officers hastily retreated from the front porch, Chief Maloney entered the line of fire, pulling critically wounded officers to the safety of a patrol car, ordering them to the Portsmouth Regional Hospital. Chief Maloney returned to the immediate vicinity of the gun battle to defend other wounded officers.

It was at that time that he was fatally wounded. Please remember this Hero and his sacrifice.

status_message:
"Osceola County sheriff's deputies have located two 16-year-old girls who went missing during a short stroll around sundown Saturday. The two were spotted in a heavily-wooded area after an ongoing search that included members of the Chabad movement, an Orthodox Jewish community, from Brevard County, surrounding counties and as far away as New York.

"They did locate the girls in the forest, very good news," said Rabbi Zvi Konikov of the Chabad of the Space and Treasure Coasts in Satellite Beach. He and six other men from Brevard County spent the night searching through the dense woods and marsh where the two girls were last seen before sundown Saturday.

Deputies said that Brocha Katz and Riva Moshe, both 16, visiting from Miami Dade. They were last seen at the Caribe Resort, located at 9000 Treasure Trove Lane in Kissimmee and possibly were taking a short stroll.  The sheriff's office dispatched its helicopters and police dogs to track the teens. Members of the Chabad also plastered posters across Kissimmee's busy tourist district.
Neither of the girls had a cellphone, money or transportation. The girls were expected to be checked for dehydration and any injuries."

J.D. Gallop - Florida Today

status_message: The Ferguson effect...it is alive and well today. Police moral is at an all time low. We can tell you, from personal experience, the job is becoming a political joke. Why would anyone want to become a Law Enforcement Officer in today's climate? We sure as hell wouldn't recommend it...it takes a level of guts and fortitude that is beyond the norm, there are not many out there with skin thick enough to take on that roll. Could you do it? For us veterans, especially those with 10 years or more on, we have to reinvent the wheel...the days of doing your job the way it is supposed to be done are out the window. Now we have to be the rainbow police...it's almost not even worth it. If you aspire to be a cop, well done, you are an amazing person...but just know, this shit is not like the movies...

Please keep Officer Smith in your prayers. 

Columbus Police SWAT Officer Steven M. Smith remains in critical condition at OSU Wexner Medical Center.  His family, friends and a Columbus Division of Police chaplain remain by his side.

SWAT Officer Smith was shot early Sunday morning while working with fellow officers to serve an arrest warrant at 14 W. California Avenue.

SWAT Officer Smith has served with the Columbus Division of Police for 27-years.  He is 54 years old.

*Be advised that the Columbus Division of Police has two officers named Steven Smith.  

Additional details will be released when they become available.

status_message:
Here at Blue Lives Matter we receive a lot of hate mail. But, we also receive a lot of positive encouragement from you guys for which we are very thankful. Here is one that we recently received and felt we just had to share:

"I am an African American young female that is torn everyday because of the confusion between the BLKM riots and the controversial ideas people are saying about the police force...just watching your videos and reading information made me confident and proud to say thank you for creating this group to stand up for the police force I would stand beside and be blessed for the LIVES you guys put on the front line to protect the citizens today the world is becoming more and more chaotic and honestly I'm nearly in tears lol because it is emotional to be so touched that you guys are really trying your hardest to let all of America know you guys aren't monsters! I feel more at ease to go into public now and I feel safer to drive now because of you guys. I am happy to know who are the bad guys and who aren't, and you guys aren't! You are guys are brave and take your jobs, especially your lives seriously. For someone, to get out of their bed and make sure someone else's life is protected before something bad happens, is a trait many people cannot obtain. Thank you! I will continue to come to your page and support Blue Lives Matter!!" -Imani Pryor
For those of you in the Richmond, VA area, come out and show your support on April 9th. Take time to honor our fallen brother and show this community you care.

WARNING: TRAGIC AND UPSETTING- this video is intended for educational purposes only. This is one of the dangers we face while working under cover. Albuquerque under cover Detective Jacob Grant was riding in a suspect vehicle during a drug sting. The vehicle was stopped by other officers, Lt. Greg Brachle approached the vehicle and did not recognize Det. Grant. He observed Grant's firearm and fired 9 times at Grant. Grant was fortunate to survive but his life will never be the same. If you are an officer, take the time to familiarise yourself with all of your coworkers in every unit. This tragedy, along with PG County MD Officer Jacai Colson could possibly have been avoided. Accidents do happen, we need to work harder at preventing them.

Randy served more than three decades as a Law Enforcement Officer and Leader with the Princeton Borough Police Dept in New Jersey and the Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Dept. in Nevada, where he is one of the most decorated officers in the departments history. He authored three successful books, "True Blue Police Stories by Those Who Have Lived Them", "A Cop's Life", and "True Blue To Protect and Serve". and the soon to be released. "THE POWER OF LEGACY, Personal Heroes of America's Most Inspiring People". He is a nationally known speaker on the topics of Leadership and Ethics in Law Enforcement. He has also appeared in several feature films, "Casino", "Fools Rush In" and "Miss Congeniality II" as well as numerous television shows such as "COPS". "Americas" Most Wanted" and "Las Vegas". He has also been featured on FOX News as a commentator regarding Law Enforcement issues and is a featured panelist on the cable TV show "FIRED UP". Randy is the host of the new podcast, THE POWER OF LEGACY".

We are honored and proud to have him as a member and voice of our team. Look for big things to come from Blue Lives Matter.

WATCH: Austin Texas, Officers have to use force to detain a combative suspect. This video is making its rounds on the net declaring that these officers used "excessive" force...well, they didn't. They used a reasonable amount of force to quickly affect an arrest. The suspect resisted and failed to comply with their orders. Unfortunately, we cannot use rear naked choke holds that make people fall asleep much like the "Viking Guy" did in the subway video, that leaves us with open hand and closed fist strikes. By striking a non compliant suspect in the head or face, we get them to release the tension in their arms as we attempt to place them in handcuffs as they resist. We do not do this job to get injured, we are not going to slap box or play two hand touch with a suspect who is actively resisting or fighting us. Also, isn't it convenient how these videos never show the beginning of the incidents?

status_message:
We post this every once in a while because we get so many questions about why we exist along with tons of hate mail...

Blue Lives Matter Mission Statement

The name of Blue Lives Matter originated from the incident in Ferguson, Missouri; however, the initiative has been a long fought battle in the history of law enforcement.  In today's evolving society, an increasing number of citizens fail to accept responsibility for their actions and attempt to escape the consequences through outward blame. Due to the nature of the profession, law enforcement personnel are seen as easy targets and are consequently bullied by slander, illegitimate complaints, frivolous law suits, and physical threats. The echo of these negative highlights by the media and political figures have only further damaged community relations, which has greatly increased the inherent threat of the profession.  We desire to change these wrongs to law enforcement and once again shed positive light on America's heroes to help boost morale and gain society's much needed support.

The goal of Blue Lives Matter is to honor and recognize the actions of law enforcement to strengthen the public support of an understandably naive society.

The members of our Armed Forces (many include law enforcement) have fought the battles overseas to give Americans the opportunity to live freely at home; however, criminals continue to prey on these rights for personal gain.  Americans deserve the right to live their lives with the full protection of the laws but must realize that certain sacrifices should not be taken in vain.  Law enforcement officers are also deserving citizens of these rights with personal lives, dreams, and families.  While these heroes and their families accept an elevated inherent risk for minimal pay, they should not be expected to make such a great sacrifice without due recognition and support.  Through strengthened support, law enforcement personnel will be provided a much needed boost in morale and can return full productivity back to the streets resulting in a safer America.

Thank you 

Blue Lives Matter Team,

status_message:
On Friday, March 11th, Officer Jessica Huber had the pleasure of being the "Mystery Reader" at Bradford Academy in Southfield, Michigan for March Reading Month. The teacher, Kaylynne Karas, who also happens to be an old schoolmate of my daughter had asked if she would come in and read "Walter the Farting Dog" by William Kotzwinkle and Glenn Murray. In this story it talks about the dad not wanting to keep the dog because of his smelly farts, however, one day those smelly farts came in handy. The family's house was broken into and the dog just so happen to let one loose and the burglars couldn't stand the smell, they had to get out of the house. As the bad guys ran out coughing and gagging they were met by the police. The dad decided to keep Walter the dog since he saved the day. This book was a perfect read in many ways,...not only was it funny but it was appropriate in showing the children that the police were there to help the family in a time of need. 

As the children listened to the story, of course they laughed and made funny noises but most of all they paid the utmost attention to Officer Huber. Officer Huber has always enjoyed reading ever since she was little. And now being able to share that enthusiasm with this class it was extra special. She reminded them that reading is very important and that they should try to read every day. 

She also made a huge emphasis on telling them that the police are there to protect people of all ages. So often children are being told by their parents that they are going to call the police and take them away for not cleaning up their toys. Or the parents tell their kids that police officers are mean and that they don't care about lives in general. Office Huber let the children know that this is untrue. She was sworn in to serve & protect and this is exactly what she will do.

The children had the opportunity afterwards to ask her questions like: What's your favorite color? What's your favorite food? What's your favorite shape? How many people are in your family? And the best one was,...how many people have you taken to jail? Watching my daughter interact with these young first graders was such a pleasure. I believe children need to be raised knowing that the police are not only there to protect them from harm but are friendly enough to approach and interact with as well. I'm pretty sure the kids loved having her come in today as their mystery reader since every one of them wanted a hug before she left and a few on the boys wanted her phone number (Lol!). 

We applaud Officer Huber and the Detroit Police Department (DPD) for showing children that the police are good people behind the badge. Thank you to all the men and women who serve and protect us.

For those that do not like particular posts we share, or just do not like the police in general, we have many people that follow our page that actually do not like the idea of law enforcement at all, but come here and join in spirited intellectual debates. We have actually become quite friendly with a few of them because they are not bad people, they just have a skewed opinion on American policing. We are perfectly okay with that because it is our goal to try to bring them into the light, to get them to understand that cops really are not murderous rights violating monsters. Everyone has their opinion and is perfectly entitled to it. Therefore, we are entitled to our opinion as well. Just because we are police officers does not mean we have to be robots that are mindless. We are people just like you. This page is a place for us to speak our minds. If you cannot live with that, that is perfectly fine, but keep it to yourself. If you bring it to our page, we will either ban you or we will challenge your negative comments...so don't get your feelings hurt when we stand for what we believe in.

status_message:
Heroes. 

The Metropolitan Police Department (MPD) recognized five officers this week for their quick response in de-escalating a situation and resolving the encounter safely.  Officers  Ammar Rahim, Perry Morgan, James Da'Re, Christopher Brown,  and Matthew Rider were presented with the Medal of Valor for their actions during an encounter that took place  on Tuesday, March 3, 2015.

At approximately 2:25 pm, the Third District Officers were dispatched to an aggravated assault call in progress at the intersection of 4th and Bryant Streets, Northwest.  The dispatcher gave a lookout for a suspect described as a black male, with dreadlocks, pushing a baby stroller.  The suspect was located by Officers Da'Re and Brown, walking southbound on 4th Street, Northwest with a knife.  The officers assumed command of the situation and requested additional units with Crisis Intervention.

status_message:
A follower of our page, Connor Webber, sent us this, thank you sir. 

"What happened to those kids who wanted to grow up to be doctors, lawyers, astronauts, and Cops? That is what I aspired to be when I was young, I wanted to be a police officer so badly. Now I see all these people condemning those who protect us. Granted many do make mistakes. Can that not be said for anyone? Everyone makes mistakes. Or has off days, if we're basing how we feel about them on how many mistakes they've made than why don't we hate lawyers? They wrongly imprison people on by mistake everyday. Why don't we hate Doctors, they kill people through their mistakes everyday as well. Why is it those who put themselves in the most risk to keep us safe are the ones we crucify the most? It is because we need that person to blame. That guinea pig to take out all of our anger on because we are truly at fault. In my eyes police officers are the most amazing people because of what they do and what they go through. Police officers remind me of what a Christian should be. Yes they make mistakes. But so do you. And quite often they are the ones who pay for your mistakes. So yes, I still aspire to be a cop, and I hope my kids have that aspiration aswell."
A 3rd grade teacher in Florida, Brittany Maria, had her students write letters to the police. Thank you Brittany!

status_message:
"A TRUE STORY"
written by Kay Waddell

Attention all units, attention all units,
I need you to respond to a man with a gun,
He's holding hostages, his wife and son,
Proceed with caution, but, get the job done!

So, with sirens blaring and blue lights flashing,
I picked up speed, as cars I was passing! 
Not wasting any time as I raced to the call,
I knew the dangers, but, I would give it my all!

There is a mad man, wife and son by his side,
With nothing to live for, he was willing to die!

The officer's entered the dark, quiet room,
When silence was shattered with a deafening boom!
He killed his son and then his wife,
He killed an officer, then took his own life!

Nothing can prepare you, not anything you can do,
When you see one of the dead is a brother in blue!
Overwhelmed with grief and a broken heart,
Can we live in peace....when will it start?
Is it even possible to live with one another,
Why do you choose to take the life of a brother?

Rest in the arms of Jesus, you Heroes in blue,
With honor and pride, we salute you!

Thank you Mayra Rodriquez for raising a great daughter. 

"Yesterday at the South Miami Arts Festival free jazz concert.....

I am with my 9 year old listening to some great jazz and she notices a few police officers walking around.  She turns to me and says "Look mommy those police officers have been walking around keeping us all safe."  I respond, "Yes, Evangeline they have, that is their job." She continues, "I know mommy and I'm sure they are very nice too."  To which I answer, "Yes, Mookie I'm sure they are very nice."  She adds, "Mommy, they have been walking around all day and I'm sure they are thirsty. Is it OK if I give them a bottle of water from the ones in our bag that we brought with us?"  I look at her in total awe and say, "Of course Mookie Bear, that is very nice of you to think of them. I'm sure they would like that very much." In conclusion she says to me, "Thanks mommy, I will give them each a bottle and I will say 'thank you' for keeping me and you safe tonight." 

WOW!!! From the mouth of babes people!!! How sad that it takes the innocence of a child to recognize effort, sacrifice and dedication but a mature adult chooses to be ignorant about it.

I may not be the perfect parent, as kids don't come with instruction manuals but I think I'm doing something right. 

KUDOS to my little Mookie Monkey Bear 
a/k/a Happy Cake!!! You make mommy very proud!!! 

Please share this and make it go viral, maybe it will make a difference and change some ignorant minds about those who serve and protect."
This little girl is a true hero. I have no words for how courageous this child was.
link_name: CHP: 10-year-old girl dies, after pushing another child to safety

status_message:
A local police station received this question from a resident through the feedback section of a local Police website:

"I would like to know how it is possible for police officers to continually harass people and get away with it?"

In response, a Sergeant posted this reply:

First of all, let me tell you this... it's not easy. In the rural area we average one cop for every 505 people. Only about 60 per cent of those cops are on general duty where we do most of our harassing.

The rest are in non-harassing units that do not allow them contact with the day to day innocents. At any given moment, only one-fifth of the 60 per cent of general duties are on duty and available for harassing people while the rest are off duty. So, roughly, one cop is responsible for harassing about 6000 residents.

When you toss in the commercial business and tourist locations that attract people from other areas, sometimes you have a situation where a single cop is responsible for harassing 15,000 or more people a day.

Now, your average eight-hour shift runs 28,800 seconds long. This gives a cop two-thirds of a second to harass a person, and then only another third of a second to drink an iced coffee AND then find a new person to harass. This is not an easy task. To be honest, most cops are not up to the challenge day in and day out. It is just too tiring. What we do is utilise some tools to help us narrow down those people we can realistically harass.

PHONE: People will call us up and point out things that cause us to focus on a person for special harassment. "My neighbour is beating his wife" is a code phrase used often. This means we'll come out and give somebody some special harassment. Another popular one is, "There's a guy breaking into a house." The harassment team is then put into action.

CARS: We have special cops assigned to harass people who drive. They like to harass the drivers of fast cars, cars with no insurance or drivers with no licences and the like. It's lots of fun when you pick them out of traffic for nothing more obvious than running a red light.  Sometimes you get to really heap the harassment on when you find they have drugs in the car, they are drunk, or have an outstanding warrant on file.

LAWS: When we don't have phone or cars, and have nothing better to do, there are actually books that give us ideas for reasons to harass folks. They are called "statutes". These include the Crimes Act, Summary Offenses Act, Land Transport Act and a whole bunch of others... They spell out all sorts of things for which you can really mess with people. After you read the law, you can just drive around for a while until you find someone violating one of these listed offenses and harass them. Just last week I saw a guy trying to steal a car. Well, the book says that's not allowed. That meant I had permission to harass this guy.

It is a really cool system that we have set up, and it works pretty well. We seem to have a never-ending supply of folks to harass. And we get away with it. Why? Because, for the good citizens who pay the tab, we try to keep the streets safe for them, and they pay us to "harass" some people.

Next time you are in the area, give me the old "single finger wave". That's another one of those codes. It means, "You can harass me." It's one of our favorites.

status_message:
A little bit of humor for your afternoon...

A motorcycle police officer stops a driver for shooting through a red light. The driver is a real jerk, steps out of his car and comes striding toward the officer, demanding to know why he is being harassed by the Gestapo!
 
So the officer calmly tells him of the red light violation. The motorist instantly goes on a tirade, questioning the officer's ancestry, 
sexual orientation, etc., in rather explicit offensive terms.
 
The tirade goes on without the officer saying anything.
 
When the officer finishes writing the ticket he puts an "AH" in the lower right corner of the narrative portion of the ticket. 
He then hands it to The 'violator' for his signature. The guy signs the ticket angrily, and when presented with his copy points
to the "AH" and demands to know what it stands for.
 
The officer says, "That's so when we go to court, I'll remember that you're 
an asshole!"
 
Two months later they're in court. The 'violator' has a bad driving record with a high number of points and is in danger of losing his license, so he hired a lawyer to represent him.
 
On the stand the officer testifies to seeing the man run through the red light.
 
Under cross examination the defense attorney asks; "Officer is this a reasonable facsimile of the ticket that you issued to my client?"
 
Officer responds, "Yes, sir, that is the defendant's copy, his signature and mine, same number at the top."
 
Lawyer: "Officer, is there any particular marking or notation on this ticket you don't normally make?"
 
"Yes, sir, in the lower right corner of the narrative there is an "AH," underlined."
 
"What does the "AH" stand for, officer?"
 
"Aggressive and hostile, Sir."
 
"Aggressive and hostile?"
 
"Yes, Sir.
 
"Officer, are you sure it doesn't stand for asshole?"
 
Well, sir, you know your client better than I do.

How often can one get an attorney to convict his own client?

status_message: On February 20th, while patrolling San Patricio County, Deputy Rachelle Farmer observed a young 13 year old male holding grocery bags walking along the roadway.  Deputy Farmer made contact with the boy to check his welfare.  The boy stated he was walking to Walmart (3.5 miles from his home) to get a few grocery's and make some returns to the store.  Deputy Farmer recognized the boy whom she had met a year earlier while participating in the "Shop with a Cop" program.  The boy told Deputy Farmer that his family was without a vehicle and that his father was not physically able to walk to the store.  The boy indicated that when there is enough money, he sometimes takes a cab.  Deputy Farmer gave the boy a ride to the local Walmart, and stayed with him until he completed his grocery shopping, then took him home.  Today, members of the San Patricio County Sheriff's office pitched in and purchased the boy a new bicycle, helmet, chain lock and back pack to make his 7 mile round trip to the store a little easier. Nice work guys.
link_name: Photos from Blue Lives Matter's post

status_message:
Please read...from one of our supporters. 

My husband came home this morning. He came in the same way he always does. Greets the dogs, enters the dining room rummaging through his gear plugging in his batteries. Pulling out his laundry placing everything in their proper place. A sigh. The usual sigh that says last night was another long night. I wrap my arms around him. I realize that I am blessed to have him in my life. He is my hero, our kids' hero. He is strong, honest, and loyal. He cares. I know there are many wives that are not greeting their husbands at the door. They aren't waiting for his call in the middle of the night. They aren't wondering whether or not he will come home late. They aren't doing these things because their husbands are gone. Their souls transcending into a better place. Their bodies left here, families in tears. These wives have been through the parade, the funeral, the flag placed in their laps. These wives, their children, mothers, fathers, brothers, sisters, and friends. These families have had their lives torn apart. Seas of blue gather to honor a hero. She stands strong because she must. She stands firm because we have always. We always stand fast, ready for anything. Except you are not ready for this. You will never be ready for this. Her tears soak her tissues, her children sit beside her. A boy holds on to his father's casket. One last hug one last good-bye. Another boy shares the same super hero shirt. Finally wearing it together only to be apart. Painful. She knew like I it could be possible. But we carry on every day. Do not think about what could be. Focus on what we have now. Every moment treasured, every moment now lingers in memories. She comes home only to a bedroom with his things right where he left them. Her house appears on pause. A time when things use to be. She sits in silence, his impressions on their bed begin to fade. His laugh, his smile, his hugs. Memories now. Good memories. His spirit will remain. Always watching, always protecting. He never treasured his life more than someone else's. She must make a statement to the news about what a good man he was. Maybe people would care, maybe not. They curse the badge. So you stay strong because he wouldn't want you to weaken. There are many faces of the badge. It isn't just his face. When you look at him see his kids, his wife, his mother, his family. When you look into his eyes see your own. Understand you are one in the same. More than just a badge. More than just blue.

-Teri Jo

status_message:
Blue Lives Matter because All Lives Matter. The brave men and women that make up the law enforcement community in America come from all walks of life, all colors of the racial spectrum, religious backgrounds, etcetera. So by us saying Blue Lives Matter, we absolutely are saying All Lives Matter. We would lay down our lives for anyone, no matter their skin tone, not matter their belief system. Why? Easy, because it is the right thing to do. Black Lives absolutely Matter to us, but no more than any other lives this world has to offer. Many of us here at Blue Lives Matter are black...and many of us are asian, Hispanic, etcetera. We are here for you, we are here as your last resort, when all else fails, we are here to do whatever we can to help you. 

Have a good evening and may whatever God or beleif system you follow bless you with happiness and good fortune.
