This is an anonymous letter that was sent to us. This heroic Officer was put in a situation that forever changed his life. It's a long read but, a good read. People need to realize that when an Officer takes someones life that the struggles of that situation are only just beginning. 

Letter to the man I killed-

Some people know this about me; others do not.  I have killed a man.  This is not a confession; it is just fact.  I have nothing to hide about it.  I am not ashamed of the fact.  I have no regrets about doing it.  I was doing my job.  At the time of your death, I was a police officer.  And, you tried your best to kill me.  I am the police officer that killed you.
I hope you were not long in your suffering, but as I am aware, during the short time I spent with you, listening to your cries of agony and for mercy, the curses you spat at me, I endured, as you bled to death.  I endured.
I hope you had a chance to reconcile with our creator before you went, and that angels bore you away to a better place.  I would have prayed with you had there been time, but there was not, so I could only pray for you.  And, occasionally I still do.
People who choose a path like the one you chose, probably don't weigh into the equation, the most dreadful consequences of their actions.  I weighed it into my own equation every day as a police officer.
I have experience with death. In fact, death and I are quite intimate with each other.  You have your death.  I died a physical death once, albeit briefly, but I was brought back.  I wondered for what, a specific event?  Your death?
I never really feared a physical death.   When I came back, that lack of fear was reaffirmed.  I suppose that made me infinitely more dangerous as an adversary, more so than someone merely chest thumping with a "nothing to lose" attitude, at the risk of sounding clich.
I took your life; I get that.  But still, you took something from me.  And, You changed me, forever.  I have been a hunter for most of my life, including a hunter of armed men.  What Hemingway said about the hunting of armed men and liking it, is true.   You never really care for anything else thereafter.  I hunt animals still, but often do not pull the trigger.  Perhaps in time, this will change.
Killing a man is nothing to take lightly.  It changes you.  It changes what people think about you.  You aren't the same person anymore.  And still, I love life.  I revel in the beauty of it, both the simplicities and intricacies of it.  I appreciate life.  This solitary act does not define me; it doesn't even scratch the surface.
People, who do not "know," talk about it as though it was no big deal, but I will tell you it is a "huge" deal.  "Get over it," "Put it behind you," "Try to not think about it," which are all great thoughts.  Were it that easy, who wouldn't? It does not work that way.  
Perhaps people would begin to understand the gravity of it, were they to see a police officer choking on the barrel of their own gun, trying to turn "it" off.  Or writing about it, with the muzzle of a gun pressed against their temple.  Some succumb to the haunting despair.  I will not. To the contrary, I consider "It" a visit from an old enemy.  I sometimes welcome the nightmares, the gore, and the violence, to let "It" know, "It" will never best me.  The outcome is the same at its base.  I live.  Whatever attacks me does not.  They fail; I survive.  When I awaken from my sleep (If you can call it that) dripping slick with sweat, heart pounding, I am still alive!
I get to relive "our" event everyday since it happened, not because I want to; I have no choice, it just comes calling whenever it feels like it, no warning; it just intrudes, multiple times a day. What triggers it?  Everything, and nothing at all.
I'm always expecting the unexpected, always aware.  I have a heightened tactical plan to kill everyone I meet. Only a police officer or soldier would understand that. It is not paranoia.  I am "situationally aware," even in my dreams.  Realistically there is always a target on my back, but that's what I signed up for when I pinned on the badge.  This is just part of what it is like to be a police officer.
Walt Whitman said, "If you done it, it ain't bragging."  But, if you haven't done it, the things I have done; your opinion, armchair quarterbacking, and constant shuffling of the "What if?" deck, really doesn't mean shit to me.
Still, my adversary, I admire your tenacity.  It was a fair fight for the most part, well you cheated a little, but still, it was a fight to the death, your death.  But I don't hate you, truth be told, I just feel sorry for you.
Oddly, I have not shed one tear for you, and I have cried many times during my career.  My lamentation over the loss of my favorite bird dog was loud, tearful, and long lasting.  Maybe because he was a true friend, and you, you were just what you were, my enemy, and that changes everything.
You made fatal mistakes, young and invincible, tough guy full of bravado whether false or real.  You had choices; you made poor ones.  I was already committed when I climbed out of my patrol car and stood on the asphalt.  Perhaps you just hesitated, or maybe, were just too slow?  The latter is obvious fact.  Everything else is merely speculation.
I would like to thank you for some things, like looking over my shoulder for the rest of my life, and for cutting my career thirteen years short.  Thanks for helping me see that my department was totally incapable of handling the shooting investigation and subsequent homicide investigation.  It perfectly illustrated the creed "A false friend is more dangerous than a known enemy."  It was a real eye opener, after many years on the job to realize that incompetent supervisors and politicians have no hesitation to hang a target on the back of a good police officer for doing his job and doing it well.
I wonder how many other officers have had their Civil Rights violated by their own departments during post-shooting investigation fiascos?  Police officers have rights too.  Please keep that in mind.  
While my career was cut short, I am thankful I would never again (at that agency) have to endure shoddy procedures and listen about my "other options" in a justified deadly-force scenario, from cowards and idiots.  Nor will I have to worry about being returned to the front lines as soon as possible without a chance to decompress, nor worry that a modicum of protection would be afforded my family, who has suffered greatly at their hands.
I remember visiting the scene of the shooting on the first anniversary of your death, not knowing what I would find there.  What I found there was absolutely nothing to mark the occasion.  There was however, a small token of remembrance there when I left.  That struck me as very sad; the only one who bothered to pay their respects was the one who put you in the ground.
Were I able, I would sit down and share a drink with you and a fine meal, I would do so before I broke bread with some of my so called "brothers" or the "politicians" from my town, who are so quick to feed us to the wolves. I mean that with the very fiber of my soul.  You were a worthy adversary.
I thank you for bringing a "real" gun to a "real" gunfight.  I thank you for turning your attention to me and leaving the younger officer alone.  I thank you for the baggage that keeps me in a perpetual state of being physically and mentally worn out.
Perhaps I'll see you on the other side, if you reconciled, and the angels came to take you away to Heaven that early summer morning.  If so, maybe we can have that drink and share a meal?
If not, you made another bad choice, infinitely worse than the first, and I will never see you again.

With Sincerity,
The police officer that killed you

status_message:
A letter sent to us, by Dan Hand:

Friends, those of you that know me know I once wore a badge and was sworn to uphold the law. There have always been those who defied the badge and my job, just as they defied the statutes I was sworn to uphold. As I watch the current events, it seems to me that war has been declared on the peacekeepers of our great nation. Admittedly, there are those wearing a badge that have either gotten into the profession for the wrong reason or have forgotten why they put the badge on in the first place.... believe me, they are the exception to the rule. Some may say that police brutality has gotten out of hand, and in a few cases I have to agree, but, keep in mind what we are asking of these servants. The vast majority of these professionals want nothing more than to serve their community, make it a safer place to live, raise children and go home to their families. We expect them to run into the gun fire while everyone else evacuates... we expect them to apprehend the drug dealer, the murderer, the domestic abuser, child molester and to work the DUI fatality on the corner that took the lives of children....and keep a smile and positive attitude.... yes, they signed up for this, but I ask.... how many of you could see these atrocities on a daily basis and continue to smile and stay positive? I ask each of you, please, say a prayer and support your local law enforcement. They are there to protect and serve and your gratitude towards them goes a long way.  Thanks for listening....
Great picture and Officer.

status_message:
WATCH: CAYCE, SC: A November 2015 incident in which two officers shot a suspect during an arrest attempt. 

Officer Rhett Kelly and Sergeant Frank Ballentine had found a small amount of marijuana in 21-year old Demetrius Shelley Bryant's pockets after questioning him about the smell of marijuana from his car. Bryant resists when the officers attempt to arrest him on drug-related charges, pulls out a pistol, and opens fire on the officers. 

Officer Kelly was wounded by one of the shots while Sergeant Ballentine chased and then fatally shot Bryant as he fled. Bryant had been arrested three times prior for gun and drug possession. Officer Kelly was later able to return to work.

Decided to get Chipotle today, was ready to check out, reached for my wallet and it wasn't there! Being extremely embarrassed I apologized and explained I couldn't pay and began to exit the restaurant. Both the check out girl, Rosa, and the man in line behind me, John, insisted I come back in. John offered to pay but Rosa insisted I just take the food. After refusing multiple times I reluctantly and graciously took my lunch. So thank you Rosa and John (and Chipotle) you made this Officers day! What can you do nice for someone today? It doesn't take much.

status_message:
Video Credit - Donut Operator

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=koZ7-Uu4NiE&feature=youtu.be

It is we the kids left to wonder
Why our parents do what they do
It is we the kids left to ponder 
why no one appreciates them too

It is we the kids that within our hearts
Hold an honor like no other
proudly we wake each and every day
With a Hero as a father or Mother

It is we the kids that bow our heads 
And pray to our Father above
That he will look out for our Heroes
And take care of those that we love

It is we the kids that miss them
On Holidays and Birthdays too
Yes it is we the kids that loan
A piece of our heart to you.

It is we the kids that are taught
The way we should always be
 Do in your heart what is right
Even when no one is watching or can see

It is we the kids of those Heroes
We carry with us their last name
They walk with Character and Honor
Raising us to do the same.

It is we the kids that too have guilt
When one of their brothers or Sisters Die
We are the children of those that survived
.And it is with their kids we the kids Cry.

It is we the kids that often feel afraid
Because of what our parents do
Do those that wish to harm them
Wish to harm we the kids too.

It is we the kids that are hurt 
When administrations make the choices they do
It is not only our parents that suffer
For we the kids are suffering too.

It is we the kids that see the tears
That roll from our Mom or Dads eyes
When that knock comes at the door 
And they tell us our Hero has Died.

It is we the kids that stand at that grave
All the while wondering why
That bad guy took our Mom or Dad
And care nothing of the tears that we cry.

It is we the kids that see that Flag
That lay on the top of the coffin that day
The one they handed our Dad or Mom
Just before they lay them in their grave.

It is we the kids that go to dances
That graduate and get married too
That are left to do it alone and praying
That from Heaven they can see all we do

It is we the kids that today
All over this Nation Cry 
When Day after Day our parents are Murdered
And no one gives a Damn as to WHY.

So next time you see the Image 
Of The Hero on TV that Died
Remember it is he that lost his life
And we the Kids that were left to Cry.

God will always take care of his Children
Hide and Watch

Hunter Pollard

status_message: Many people have asked, why did you become the Police? Well, there are a lot of variables to that question. Yes, of course there is the excitement, the endorphin rush of driving code to the unknown, the thrill of the danger. However, whether we like to admit it or not, it is the altruistic nature ingrained in us that steers us towards this calling. The need to help others. The desire to save those who cannot help themselves. When the big picture of it all is examined, any one of us would take a bullet for a stranger. We would bend over backwards to get to the truth of the most miniscule of matters. Yes we have horrendous senses of humor, yes we make disgusting jokes about the heinous, but that is just our blanket of protection. In the end, we just want what is right, what is expected, what should be done. Sometimes the truth hurts, but we will always stand behind it.
And another....will update when we know more. Please keep this Officer in prayer.

status_message: WATCH IN ITS ENTIRETY: DC Police (6th District) attempt to affect an arrest but the subject resists. A loud and apparently violent crowd quickly forms around them. So now they have to worry about multiple threats. These officers show great restraint dealing with the situation. The arestee can be heard shouting "I can't breath, help help, I can't breath" (it takes quite a bit of breath to shout like that.) Suspects now will do anything they can to make themselves appear the victim, especially when they know they are being recorded. Could you handle this day in and day out knowing that not only do you have to deal with that, but also the media and public scrutiny, as well as the possibility of your departments caving to said scrutiny by making you a scapegoat?

status_message:
On Highway 109

A drunk man in an Oldsmobile 
They said had run the light 
That caused the six car pileup 
On 109 that night. 

When broken bodies lay about 
And blood was everywhere, 
The sirens screamed out eulogies, 
For death was in the air. 

A mother, trapped inside her car, 
Was heard above the noise; 
Her plaintive plea near split the air: 
Oh, God, please spare my boys! ' 

She fought to loose her pinned hands; 
She struggled to get free, 
But mangled metal held her fast 
In grim captivity 

Her frightened eyes then focused 
On where the back seat once had been, 
But all she saw was broken glass and 
Two children's seats crushed in. 

Her twins were nowhere to be seen; 
She did not hear them cry, 
And then she prayed they'd been thrown free, 
Oh, God, don't let them die! ' 

Then firemen came and cut her loose, 
But when they searched the back, 
They found therein no little boys, 
But the seat belts were intact. 

They thought the woman had gone mad 
And was traveling alone; 
But when they turned to question her, 
They discovered she was gone. 

Policemen saw her running wild 
And screaming above the noise 
In beseeching supplication, 
Please help me find my boys! 

They're four years old and wear blue shirts; 
Their jeans are blue to match.' 
One cop spoke up, 'They're in my car, 
And they don't have a scratch. 

They said their daddy put them there 
And gave them each a cone, 
Then told them both to wait for Mom 
To come and take them home. 

I've searched the area high and low, 
But I can't find their dad. 
He must have fled the scene, 
I guess, and that is very bad.' 

The mother hugged the twins and said, 
While wiping at a tear, 
'He could not flee the scene, you see, 
For he's been dead a year.' 

The cop just looked confused and asked, 
'Now, how can that be true? ' 
The boys said, 'Mommy, Daddy came 
And left a kiss for you.' 

He told us not to worry 
And that you would be all right, 
And then he put us in this car with 
The pretty, flashing light. 

But, We wanted him to stay with us, 
Because we miss him so, 
But Mommy, he just hugged us tight 
And said he had to go. 

He said someday we'd understand 
And told us not to fuss, 
And he said to tell you, Mommy, 
He's watching over us.' 

The mother knew without a doubt 
That what they spoke was true, 
For she recalled their dad's last words, 
'I will watch over you.' 

The firemen's notes could not explain 
The twisted, mangled car, 
And how the three of them escaped 
Without a single scar. 

But on the cop's report was scribed, 
In print so very fine, 
An angel walked the beat tonight 
On Highway 109.

by Selena Readmond
Rest in peace loyal friend. Thank you for your service.

Monte is a Loveland Police Department K9 and he has been entered into a national Facebook photo contest for a free Kevlar vest. He is the only K9 that was entered in Colorado. The contest is a photo "like" contest and the top 5 dogs receive a free vest. The likes have to be on the original picture from the link below. There have already been 8 K9's killed this year and 4 of them by gunfire.

In addition, one of the contest rules is that the name of a fallen officer has to be stitched on the vest.  This unit has chosen to dedicate the vest to fallen Trooper Jamie Jursevics.  Her husband DJ has allowed us to honor her with her name and EOW date being embroidered on Monte's vest- if he wins. The contest ends February 13th at midnight. Check it out please!

status_message:
A Police Officer

By: Andrew Smierciak

He carries himself tall, walking with a puffed chest and chin high. He wears a uniform, on it a name tag and shield his marking his organization of which he is family . He has a belt, but not like yours or mine on his he carries his life, he carries your life he carries with him the protection of the city. His own protection weaved into a vest of fiber and velcro tucked under his pressed uniform.  He wears shoes, but not like mine or yours his shoes must bear the weight of the city they must be sturdy. He sleeps like you and I he eats like you and I he dreams, he cries, he bleeds, like you and I. He is human like you and I. 

Yesterday he buried his best friend his brother, he cried as he handed a folded flag to a little boy. A little boy who stood firm and strong, because he knew his father was strong, and as he stood there unwavering a volley of rifle fire sounded and another, and another, it was over. Yesterday a son lost a father, a wife lost a husband, a mother and father lost a son, a city shield has been cracked.

Last week he carried a blanket to a woman, but not a regular woman. This woman was dead, she was hit by a drunk driver who left her there to die. He was there when she died, he heard her very last words, he held her hand while she cried and tried to comfort her. He watched the life flee from her eyes as paramedics worked vigorously to keep her alive. Last week he carried a blanket, he carried loss, he carried fear, he carried pain, and he will carry it forever.

Last month he held a child the most precious gift in life, but this child was not his. This child belonged to the woman covered in track marks, the father who was nowhere to be seen. This child was hungry, this child was skinny, this child was afraid. He held her firm, he fed her, he covered her, protected her. He will protect her forever.

Today he walks strange today he walks nervous but calm. Today he stands in front of a gun, but not his own. He must be firm as his fear overwhelms his senses, he must be a shield he must protect his city, his family. Today he will be yesterday, he will be last week, today he will be last month, today he will be A Police Officer.

The New Mexico Fire and Police Pipes and Drums play for line of duty funerals all over and need support to keep this going. They are non profit and rely on donations and raising money through sales. Check this out and support if you can.

*Quick* disclaimer....

This page is run by cops for cops and their supporters. We say it like it is, speak our mind, share our opinions. You get it right from the horse's mouth with us, no sugar coating. 

For those of you who are sensitive and walk the world with blinders on, this page is not for you. We are not politically correct (our name should have given that away,) nor will we ever be. 

We will not post negative things about police officers, that is not what this page is for. If you wish to read about the less than one percent of one percent of Cops who ruin it for the rest of us, you will not find that content here. We support our brothers and sisters in blue.

If you have thin skin...well, perhaps you should take a ride with one of us for a day or two...get that skin a little thicker...

Thankfully Dinkheller's murderer was just executed for his heartless and disturbing actions on that day.

status_message:
This poem was originally posted by Canton police officer Frank Ranalli in honor of K9 Jethro. 

"The Life Of A Police Dog"

"You brought me home
One sunny day
With you for years
I would surely stay."

"I met your pack
Children and wife
I began to love
My new-found life."

"I slept on your couch
At the foot of your bed
You looked at me lovingly
While petting my head."

"We trained for months
And our bonding grew
We were both partners
Buddies in Blue."

"We did school demo's
And I never did wrong
Over all of the years
My love for you grew strong."

"How I loved to work
To stand up and bark
In the back of our car
From light until dark."

"We went call to call
Having fun all the way
Until the call came
On that one fateful day."

"A man with a gun
The dispatcher did say
I jumped from my car
When it pointed your way."

"Before leaving home I was told
"keep him safe" by your wife
I knew at that moment
For you I would give my life."

"The bullet struck hard
Steady and true
The bullet struck me instead
Of striking you."

"When you go home tonight
Tell your wife I did good
Strong, Tall and Proud 
On the ground that I stood."

"I'm dead and gone now 
This much is true
But I've done my job well
Of protecting you."

"Thank you
Loyal partner,
Faithful friend,
You will be greatly missed."

status_message: "A woman stopped a Philadelphia police officer on the street Saturday night to warn police about other allegedly radicalized men like the gunman accused of shooting a Philadelphia cop several days ago, according to an incident report. According to the Saturday night incident report obtained by ABC News, the woman, listed as anonymous, said that the threat to police is not over. She said Archer is part of a group consisting of three others and that he is not the most radical of the four. The report said the three other men frequent the area where the shooting took place and that officers should be careful there. While the report did not mention Archer by name, it said the defendant attended a mosque in Philadelphia and became more radical after attending a second mosque nearby."

status_message:
Blue Lives Matter Mission Statement

The name of Blue Lives Matter originated from the incident in Ferguson, Missouri; however, the initiative has been a long fought battle in the history of law enforcement.  In today's evolving society, an increasing number of citizens fail to accept responsibility for their actions and attempt to escape the consequences through outward blame. Due to the nature of the profession, law enforcement personnel are seen as easy targets and are consequently bullied by slander, illegitimate complaints, frivolous law suits, and physical threats. The echo of these negative highlights by the media and political figures have only further damaged community relations, which has greatly increased the inherent threat of the profession.  We desire to change these wrongs to law enforcement and once again shed positive light on America's heroes to help boost morale and gain society's much needed support.

The goal of Blue Lives Matter is to honor and recognize the actions of law enforcement to strengthen the public support of an understandably naive society.

The members of our Armed Forces (many include law enforcement) have fought the battles overseas to give Americans the opportunity to live freely at home; however, criminals continue to prey on these rights for personal gain.  Americans deserve the right to live their lives with the full protection of the laws but must realize that certain sacrifices should not be taken in vain.  Law enforcement officers are also deserving citizens of these rights with personal lives, dreams, and families.  While these heroes and their families accept an elevated inherent risk for minimal pay, they should not be expected to make such a great sacrifice without due recognition and support.  Through strengthened support, law enforcement personnel will be provided a much needed boost in morale and can return full productivity back to the streets resulting in a safer America.

Let us know if you have anymore questions. 

Thank you 

Blue Lives Matter Team,

status_message:
On Dec 12th at the Leavenworth National Cemetery, we lost a great Marine.  This Marine was participating in the Wreaths Across America event and placing a final wreath on his Son-in-law's headstone when he collapsed.  One of my Leavenworth VA Police Officers who is also a former Marine (OFC Lancaster) responded and performed CPR until the EMTs arrived.  

Our Nation and his family lost a true patriot on this day.  From the Eastern Kansas VA Police to the Kaffenberger family, our hearts and prayers go out to you during this holiday season.

Nice work Sgt Lawrence. 

Dear Sheriff McCabe,

I would like to take this opportunity to thank the Mohave County Sheriff's Office and particularly Sgt. Brandon Lawrence for going far beyond the call of duty to help one of our employees.

On Nov. 25, while working on a jobsite in Chino Valley, Ariz., one of our employees received the tragic news that his 12-year-old daughter had taken her own life in Kingman. When our employee arrived at his home in Kingman, he was met by representatives from the Mohave County Sheriff's Office.

When a tragedy like this strikes, it affects so many people in so many different ways. Sgt. Lawrence distinguished himself and the Mohave County Sheriff's Office in the caring and compassionate way he responded.

His thoughtful and compassionate response to and with our employee and his family on the day of the tragic event was amazing and most appreciated. But then, in consideration of the remaining family and the Thanksgiving holiday, Sgt. Lawrence purchased and delivered a full Thanksgiving dinner to the family of our grieving employee. When our company offered to reimburse him for the expense, he declined to accept our offer. 

I have to tell you, Sheriff McCabe, that gesture goes way, way beyond being a good public servant. I am humbled by Sgt. Lawrence's gift and devotion to our community. I don't have the words to express my gratitude. 

However, I can and do know that Sgt. Lawrence's selfless actions made an amazing difference for our grieving employee during the time of his darkest hour.

Please pass on to Sgt. Lawrence and your entire department our thanks and gratitude for the caring and compassionate response they offered to our employee. Their response is a model for our nation and exemplifies that we are all "our brother's keeper."

Respectfully and sincerely,

John Hansen, chief operating officer

Laron

From Anonymous to Her Husband: 

My husband is a Police Officer but that's not all he is. Above all he is a man of God, he is a husband who loves me and leads me, he is a father who trains and plays with his son; a son, a brother, a cousin, a friend... He works hard at a job that pays too little and is unappreciated by many. He comes home in the early morning hours after working all night protecting our community. He awakes only hours later to be with his wife and son. He struggles with all the same things as everyone else; But he first seeks God's Will which helps him remain strong and on the right path. This man I have known for 10 years. He is the love of my life and my best friend. 

And now people define him as someone who is hateful and prejudice against a certain type of person. These things have been said to his face for doing his job. People so hateful and blind that they say only one type of life matters and act like your a racist if you say All Life Matters. They are blinded by satans grip on this world. The devil tries to create division and dissensions among men to distract them away from God. This is exactly what is happening. Judging all officers is the same as judging any type of person based on appearance or color. In our home we value all life and we renounce the influence of the devil who tempts us to believe his lies.

My husband is a man. A great man in my eyes. A man that works, struggles, loves, feels, lives, breathes; a man who has fears, dreams, and thoughts. Minimizing him to just a police officer devalues all that he is. I am proud of my husbands job. He serves those in need and intercedes for people that need help in ways that many of us cannot. He serves our community, our family, and most importantly he serves God.
Absolutely

Racism and Police
WATCH: Two school resource Officers get maliciously verbally abused and taunted by the same students they took an oath to protect.

In a recent article, the HuffPost ignorantly accused the Blue Lives Matter movement of purposefully drowning out the voices for racial equality in police work.  
   While the media serves a focal point for worldwide events, we are constantly reminded how politically biased and misinformed opinions can exacerbate rising tensions.  
   These unethical articles abuse the right to Freedom of Speech and only attempt to achieve cheap attention at the cost of public safety and peace.  As law enforcement, we continue to maintain our oath both on-duty and off to uphold the law and rights of every person despite race, ethnicity, sexual orientation, disability, or gender.   Unfortunately, members of the press are not held to the same standard and continue to publish disgraceful articles that take advantage of American trust. 
   Instead of earning honest business, these outlets continue to thrive off of the publishing of misleading and controversial publications in exchange for increased views and ratings.    

 The article, linked below, was written by "journalist" Julia Craven. Here is a quote from her "About Me" page:

"Julia Craven is a politics reporter for The Huffington Post. A recent graduate of UNC Chapel Hill, she enjoys occasional Twitter trolling, goofy viral videos and writing articles that make 90% of Americans feel uncomfortable."

Well Julia, the Colorado FOP said it best, please read their quote in this image, it describes you well. 

http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/true-color-blue-lives-matter_565de1f9e4b079b2818beacd

status_message:
Great poem written by one of our page supporters Janey Brooks...

I open my eyes, wake up & out of bed to see
__ Today is the start of new & dangerous day for me. 
Not a job but a choice, a childhood dream come true
__It's what I now represent that makes My Blood Run Blue, 
The badge, the gun, the gear I shall proudly wear, 
__My Blood Runs Blue as I recite a private prayer.
I made a lengthy promise to protect & serve,
 __My Blood Runs Blue as criminals begin to see how I gained the nerve. 
Our city, our people, our streets I chose to guard, 
 __My Blood Runs Blue so innocent minds shall not be scarred.
I will not let them happen any crimes near me.
__My Blood Runs Blue as I provide safety while I watch to see.
I'll be there to stop any crime, answer any call, any need.
__My Blood Runs Blue as I jail criminals not allow them to breed.
This time like others, I'm ready to answer the next call.
__My Blood Runs Blue w/my promise of getting justice for us all.
We've lost many Officers of great will & never-forgotten might.
__My Blood Runs Blue to honor them in this never-ending fight.
It's my brothers & sisters our American districts spread so far & wide.
__My Blood Runs Blue as we leave a criminal no place to hide.
I never want to lose innocence to any violence, any crime.
__My Blood Runs Blue to weaken it not strengthen over time.
I now end this tale, this shift, this night as my home I now see.
__My Blood Runs Blue so I appreciate my life as it is meant to be.
However if I ever must answer to which God plays the part,
__My Blood Runs Blue as I answer it with only a protectors pride in my heart.
If I ever must answer the call
This is a really great story of a very amazing man.

Kyle L. Canty, a native New Yorker, went before Canada's Immigration and Refugee Board in Vancouver and asked the country to grant him refugee status.

That's the official term for political asylum-seekers granted permission to remain, work and live in another country. Canty told Canadian immigration officials that after living in seven different states, he has faced what he describes as harassment and undue targeting by police in each one of them because he is a black man. And, Canty says, the recent spate of high-profile cases involving alleged police misconduct and black male private citizens have only affirmed his fears that this pattern might wind up costing him his life.
link_name: A black American man is applying for refugee status in Canada, citing police racism. Don't laugh.

"The charge surrounds an assault on an officer back in March where Lutwama punched a Clay County Sheriff's deputy. The criminal complaint says the deputy pulled over Lutwama's friend on a traffic violation, when Lutwama attempted to free his friend from police custody.

The complaint goes on to say that Lutwama punched the officer in the face and head several times. The officer tried to push Lutwama off of him but, he continued to punch him. Moorhead Firefighters assisted the officer and had to lay on top of Lutwama to keep him from struggling. A firefighter and sheriffs deputy were injured in the incident."
link_name: Deputies, Police & Firefighters Protest Clay County Court Hearing

status_message:
Because we keep getting asked...

The name of Blue Lives Matter originated from the incident in Ferguson, Missouri; however, the initiative has been a long fought battle in the history of law enforcement.  In today's evolving society, an increasing number of citizens fail to accept responsibility for their actions and attempt to escape the consequences through outward blame. Due to the nature of the profession, law enforcement personnel are seen as easy targets and are consequently bullied by slander, illegitimate complaints, frivolous law suits, and physical threats. The echo of these negative highlights by the media and political figures have only further damaged community relations, which has greatly increased the inherent threat of the profession.  We desire to change these wrongs to law enforcement and once again shed positive light on America's heroes to help boost morale and gain society's much needed support.

The goal of Blue Lives Matter is to honor and recognize the actions of law enforcement to strengthen the public support of an understandably naive society.

The members of our Armed Forces (many include law enforcement) have fought the battles overseas to give Americans the opportunity to live freely at home; however, criminals continue to prey on these rights for personal gain.  Americans deserve the right to live their lives with the full protection of the laws but must realize that certain sacrifices should not be taken in vain.  Law enforcement officers are also deserving citizens of these rights with personal lives, dreams, and families.  While these heroes and their families accept an elevated inherent risk for minimal pay, they should not be expected to make such a great sacrifice without due recognition and support.  Through strengthened support, law enforcement personnel will be provided a much needed boost in morale and can return full productivity back to the streets resulting in a safer America.

"There's a major effort underway to let a lot of people out of jail, ostensibly less violent offenders," he said. "But one of the issues of concern is when people go to jail, oftentimes they go to jail with negotiated charges, if you will, so that somebody that is in jail that seems that they're a nonviolent drug offender may in fact have crimes of violence in their record."

EXACTLY...not to mention, these "nonviolent" people are the ones who were selling drugs to your children...

"D.C. police officers don't have the option of using a less lethal tool, such as a Taser. If they had had used a Taser, these officers could have been able to end this situation without getting into a physical altercation with someone who appears to have been under the influence of PCP or another mind-altering substance."

PCP is a beast of its own. The majority of the general public has no idea what it is like to place an individual who is high on PCP and willing to fight, in custody. These officers did what they had to in order to control this individual. It's not a pretty job, it is not like the movies.

status_message:
Thanks for the support guys! 

"In order to show support and appreciation for our nation's law enforcement, I am calling on innkeepers all over the country to show their support by offering a free night for law enforcement officers on or around National Law Enforcement Appreciation Day, January 9, 2016. Law enforcement officers put their lives on the line everyday for our communities and our country and it is time we give back and show them our support. As an owner of a bed and breakfast, I am opening my business doors and offering several nights free to show my support and appreciation for our nation's law enforcement. I encourage all innkeepers that are able to participate to list their free nights on this page. I am asking that this be a "no strings attached" offer in which at least one night is offered free, despite how many total nights the guest chooses to stay. Depending on the size of your inn, you could offer one room or multiple rooms, whatever works best for your situation. Innkeepers: when posting your free listing, please include your location, which night you can offer free to law enforcement, your website and other contact information. This page will be shared by various law enforcement groups here on Facebook to help get the word out so law enforcement officers can contact the various innkeepers directly to book their free night. Thank you for your support and participation in this new program that I hope will be a great success for future years to come!"

status_message:
A retired Sheriffs Officer out of New Jersey is working hard to start New Jersey's Law Enforcement Appreciation Day just as Texas has done. Please read the letter he wrote us below and help out if you can! 

"Please be advised that I have reached out to several New Jersey Assemblyman/woman about an idea I had for a Law Enforcement Officers Appreciation Day in New Jersey. I wrote to them requesting that they write up a resolution and get it to the Governors desk ASAP. As we all know the Democrats are anti- law enforcement and side with the racist organizations and condone their hatred of law enforcement. I have been talking with Assemblyman Parker Space's Chief of Staff Lou Crescitelli almost every day for the several weeks (who he & Parker loved my idea) and last week he informed me he has the rough draft written up and will get it out soon.I also let him know that the Governor of Texas did it and he asked me to get him the info so I sent him the Texas Governor's Executive Action. Well yesterday Assemblyman Parker Space's Chief of Staff Lou Crescitelli emailed me the final draft/letter of my idea and sent it to Governor Christie requesting that he take executive action on my resolution on a "Police Lives DO Matter" day for January 9th of every year,also Assemblyman Parker Space will draft a joint legislative resolution stating "Police Lives DO Matter" for introduction (wording can change to, New Jersey's Law Enforcement Appreciation Day). I just want to personally thank Assemblyman Parker Space and his Chief of Staff Lou Crescitelli on not only responding to my email & phone call but took the time to call me several times to talk more about it and to make sure they write it up correctly. They are both very PRO -LEO and loved my idea from the get go. Lets hope the Governor gets this done ASAP. We need to see what elected officials in the Assembly & Senate that will support this, we will then know who is with us and who is against us. This is the letter that was written/drafted and sent to Governor Christie for his hopefully Executive Action ASAP. Also I need everyone to call ( 609-292-6000) or email the Governor (http://nj.gov/governor/contact/) and ask him to support and sign this executive action/resolution ASAP. #bluelivesmatter #policelivesmatter #newjerseylawenforcementappreciationday

Tony Lepore The Dancing Cop is a retired police officer who boycotted a business, because of a worker who wrote on a coffee cup "Black Lives Matter" which she gave to an on duty police officer.

Tony`s group Citizens4Police asked for a firing of the employee, and a apology, and never received it from her, or the owner. Tony boycotted the business for four days, and that didn`t work. So he then picketed the business. Now, because of some community group who seem to be a anti-cop are asking for his firing from the Providence Christmas Traffic Event in Downtown in December.

Tony has been doing this event for 30 years, and is quite popular and people say he is as much Christmas, as Santa.

Please sign this petition to keep him doing this event for the shoppers, businesses and tourist who visit. Because he is world renowned and a big attraction to many. please sign petition .Thank you!

status_message:
You might not see this in the news but we wanted to make sure the story got out there. Heroes! 

Via Amanda Mangan with the Allegany Radio Corporation...

Two Allegany County, MD Sheriff's Deputies are being credited with saving a 90 year old woman's life. On Sunday evening Cpl. J.M. Dowden and Deputy C. Hill responded to the Frostburg area for a check on well-being call, of a 90 year old female. The son, who resides out of town, had been unable to make contact with his mother by phone for several days.
When deputies arrived on the scene they received no answer at the residence and was unable to observe anyone through the windows. The front door to the residence was found unlocked and due to the circumstances elected to enter the residence.
Upon entering the living room area the announced their presence and heard a muffled voice coming from an adjacent room. Upon enter the hallway; deputies observed the elderly female lying on the bathroom floor, pinned between the toilet and a wall.
Cpl. Dowden and Deputy Hill were able to remove her from the pinned position and carried her to the living room. The 911 center was contacted and Frostburg Area Ambulance was dispatched to that location. It was unknown how long the female subject had fallen but appears that she could have been at this location for over a day. She was transported to WMRMC.
According to Sheriff Craig " I would personally like to commend both deputies for their response and quick thinking during this incident, which resulted in saving a life. Also, my thoughts and prayers to the female subject on a speedy recovery."
Uh oh~~~~

status_message:
"Those who fight monsters inevitably change. Because of all that they see and do, they lose their innocence, and a piece of their humanity with it. If they want... to survive, they begin to adopt some of the same characteristics as the monsters they fight. It is necessary. They become capable of rage, and extreme violence. 

There is a fundamental difference, however. They keep those monster tendencies locked away in a cage, deep inside. That monster is only allowed out to protect others, to accomplish the mission, to get the job done.....Not for the perverse pleasure that the monsters feel when they harm others. In fact, those monster tendencies cause damage...GUILT, ISOLATION, DEPRESSION, PTSD. There is a cost for visiting violence on others when you are not a monster. Those who do so know one thing...The cost inflicted upon society as a whole is far greater without those who fight monsters. That is why they are willing to make that horrible sacrifice so that others may live peaceably.

Before you judge one of us, remember this...
We witness things that humans aren't meant to see...and we see them repeatedly. We perform the duties that you feel are beneath you. We solve your problems... Often by visiting violence upon others. We run towards the things that you run away from. We go out to fight what you fear. We stand between you, and the monsters that want to damage you. You want to pretend that they don't exist, but we know better. We do the things that the vast majority are too soft, too weak, too cowardly to do. 

Your life is more peaceful.....because of us.
The current political climate in this country holds that there is nothing worth fighting for. Submission is the popular mantra. Warriors are decried, denigrated, and cast as morally inferior. We know how childish, how asinine, and how cowardly that mindset is. 
We know this.....There ARE things worth fighting, and dying for. We know that not every problem can be solved through rational discourse...that some problems can only be solved through the application of force and violence. And, while we do prefer the former....we are perfectly capable of the latter. 
We believe that fighting what others fear is honorable, noble, and just....and are willing to pay the price for that deeply held belief. Why? For us, it isn't a choice...

It is what we are. We are simply built that way."

John Slensby

status_message:
On September 11, 2001, the resolve of our great nation was tested by 19 terrorists in their ruthless and cowardly attacks against the United State of America.  The intent of the armed assailants quickly became evident to the Americans on Flight 93, which bravely confronted the imminent threat and sacrificed their lives in order to save the lives of many more.  As the world stood in shock, first responders throughout the country stepped up during the moment of crisis to help restore safety and order to a society in distress.  Unfortunately, these brave acts did not come without a price.  Among the 2,977 casualties were a total of 403 first responders that lost their lives on that infamous day of American heroism.  Throughout the following 14 years, more than 500 additional first responders passed away due to health-related issues from answering their nation's call on that day.

The actions performed by these heroes (Law Enforcement, Firefighters, EMS, Dispatchers, and Military) both living and deceased will never be forgotten... Thank you for your bravery, service, and sacrifice!

status_message:
We were recently asked what we are all about, what our purpose is, and why we are called Blue Lives Matter. This was our response:

The name of Blue Lives Matter originated from the incident in Ferguson, Missouri; however, the initiative has been a long fought battle in the history of law enforcement.  In today's evolving society, an increasing number of citizens fail to accept responsibility for their actions and attempt to escape the consequences through outward blame. Due to the nature of the profession, law enforcement personnel are seen as easy targets and are consequently bullied by slander, illegitimate complaints, frivolous law suits, and physical threats. The echo of these negative highlights by the media and political figures have only further damaged community relations, which has greatly increased the inherent threat of the profession.  We desire to change these wrongs to law enforcement and once again shed positive light on America's heroes to help boost morale and gain society's much needed support.

The goal of Blue Lives Matter is to honor and recognize the actions of law enforcement to strengthen the public support of an understandably naive society.

The members of our Armed Forces (many include law enforcement) have fought the battles overseas to give Americans the opportunity to live freely at home; however, criminals continue to prey on these rights for personal gain.  Americans deserve the right to live their lives with the full protection of the laws but must realize that certain sacrifices should not be taken in vain.  Law enforcement officers are also deserving citizens of these rights with personal lives, dreams, and families.  While these heroes and their families accept an elevated inherent risk for minimal pay, they should not be expected to make such a great sacrifice without due recognition and support.  Through strengthened support, law enforcement personnel will be provided a much needed boost in morale and can return full productivity back to the streets resulting in a safer America.

status_message:
A conversation between an off duty white officer driving his cruiser to a 711, renting a movie from a Redbox, and an elderly black woman today (9/01/15):

Woman: "Officer, what do you think you are doing?"

Officer: "I'm sorry mam?"

Woman: "Don't you know your not allowed to have a           normal life? You can't be running around like a normal person enjoying life, you're waisting my tax dollars." 

She then laughs and says: "I'm just kidding, it's refreshing to see you in regular clothes, makes you look normal. I think what's happening to you is terrible. I went through it, you shouldn't have to. It's not your fault. You are a good person, I don't know you, but I know your a good person because you do a job that you couldn't pay me a million bucks to do. Don't let this garbage get you down. I appreciate you."

Officer, (stunned at this point holding his DVD): "Thank you, I'm sorry, sorry that it has come to this, but thank you."

Woman: "Sorry? For what? For being white and a police officer? That would be like me saying I'm sorry I was a black woman in the 60's. You have nothing to be sorry for."

Woman: "Go on now, give me a hug and go home and watch that movie, have a beer, and make your woman happy."

The officer proceeds to hug the woman and then goes home with a huge smile. 

That officer is this admin. (Just one of the many admins of this page)  Have a wonderful day.

status_message:
From a co-worker (not original source):

WHAT POLICE WANT THE PUBLIC TO KNOW-

Your 5 year old kid getting pushed down by another 5 year old kid is NOT a 
police matter; talk to the other kid's parents, not the police.
 
If your kid won't do his homework or do his chores, 911 is not the answer.

If a cop causes a car accident we usually get a ticket, and sometimes we get 
suspended. When is the last time you got 3 days off (without pay) for 
rear-ending a
guy at Wal-Mart.

If you think you can fan all the pot smoke out of the car before we smell 
it, good luck.

We know you've had more than two beers. When I've had two beers, I didn't 
hit six parked cars, drive my car through the front doors of a Toys-R-Us, 
piss my
pants or pass out at a traffic light.

When you see an emergency vehicle behind you with its lights and sirens on, 
pull to the RIGHT, and stop. We are usually required to pass cars on the 
left.

When you're driving in the fast lane and you see a cop behind you, don't go 
5 MPH under the speed limit. We are not impressed by how safe of a driver 
you can
be, we're trying to go help someone (or catch that guy in the SUV that just 
cut you off). Safely move over and let us pass please.

If you get a warning instead of a ticket from a motorcycle cop, go buy a 
lottery ticket, because you've already beaten the odds.

When you see an officer conducting a traffic stop, or with a suspect in 
handcuffs, it is generally not a good idea to approach him and ask for 
directions. If
 you do, don't expect the officer to be nice when he tells you to get lost, 
and don't expect the officer to take the time to explain.

Here's how to get out of a ticket. Don't break the law.

If you drive a piece of crap, that is why you're getting pulled over.
 
In one week I pulled over 10 cars for minor equipment violations.
5 out of 10 had no vehicle insurance.
3 out of 10 had suspended driver's licenses.
2 out of 10 had warrants.
1 out of 10 had felony warrants.
1 was a known sex offender with his 12 year old niece in the car without her 
mothers knowledge.
 
If you've just been pulled over doing 70 in a 35, do not greet the officer 
with "what seems to be the problem, officer?"
 
We get coffee breaks too, and sometimes we run into stores and do some 
shopping during them.

When you're the victim of a burglary, take the time you spend waiting for 
 the officer to find the model #s and the serial #s of the stuff that was 
taken.

 Some cops are just jerks, but take heart in the fact that other cops don't 
like them either.

If it's nighttime and you're driving a vehicle with tinted windows and I 
pull you over, it's not because of your skin color. I usually can't tell if 
the
vehicle even has a driver until the windows rolled down.

Every time you hear on the news about people running away from a crazed 
gunman, someone's son or daughter in a police uniform is running TOWARD that 
crazed
gunman.

Yes it's true, cops usually don't give other cops tickets. Think of it as an 
employee discount, perk or benefit. Other cops are family and you wouldn't 
give your
brother a ticket if you were a cop either.

If your local police agency has a helicopter, everyone knows it's loud and 
annoying, but did you know it can cover the same area as 20 patrol officers 
and
safely chase criminals that are driving 90 MPH through city streets. Many 
times the guy has no idea it's there and slows down.

 Police work is.......writing reports.

If you rob a gas station you're only going to get about $100, but I get to 
see a K9 dog use your arm as a chew toy. For all I care you can keep the 
 $100.

 In one year of patrol work in a large city, only about ten minutes would be 
 cool enough to be on the television show Cops.
 
Every traffic stop could end in gunfire, but we have to be polite and 
 professional until that time.

 I've taken about the same amount of men and women to jail for domestic 
 violence, so NO it's not always the man. (Simply not true, it is 85% the guy 
 that's goin' to jail on these calls)

People love fire fighters.

If the light was yellow, we wouldn't be having this conversation.
 
 Cops know you pay taxes and that your taxes pay cops' salaries. Cops also 
 pay taxes, which also pay cops' salaries so, hey, this traffic stop is on 
 me. Now sign
here; press hard. There are five copies
Yeah...but wait, who are the racist ones? So confused...

status_message:
A tribute to fallen Memphis Officer Bolton via one of our followers:

When the shot rang out in Memphis 
 Another Hero lost his life
 He lay it all down for his brother 
 He paid the ultimate price.

When he pinned on that badge this morning
 And made that traffic stop tonight alone
 One would never have believed an Americans bullet
 Would have taken him to his heavenly home

He fought for his County in Iraq
 With the greatest fighting force ever seen
 He was not only a Hero in Memphis
 He was a United States Marine.

Who could have ever dreamed
 He would survive in a Foreign land 
 And die in the streets of Memphis 
 At the hands of an American.

We should all be honored to have had him
 Protecting us each and every day
 And find comfort in knowing the Hero among us
 So loved his Country this way.

And we should also find Peace in our hearts
 When in our mind we picture the scene
 When he enter the gates of Heaven 
 He was welcomed by Brothers and Marines. 

And when we see the end of our watch
 It will be such a Honor That Day 
 To Have our Brother An American Hero
 Meet us at the gate that same way

Fly High and Semper Fi
 We will Take it from Here
 We know an Angel has got our Six
 And will feel safer knowing he is near.

You will walk among Heroes in Heaven
 Sean Bolton Walk with your Head Held High
 For you were a True American Hero
 Even after the shot rang out and you died.

God Always Takes Care of Heroes
 God will now love one of our own
 Hide and Watch

Hunter Pollard

status_message: As law enforcement, we place ourselves in positions that significantly increase the probability of lethal force in even the most minor of calls (domestic disputes, shopliftings, residential alarms, collisions)... it ultimately comes as part of the job.  While directives/general orders play a major ADMINISTRATIVE role in our profession, they are simply rules written by individuals behind a desk (usually for a reason) and at times can be permitted to be broken.  If the Officer's reaction was against procedure, then the officer should be held accountable for it within the department; however, it should not give an individual the right to further violate the law and willfully endanger an officer's safety.  As with all of the previous cases, we refuse to pass judgment on any members of our family without ALL of the facts... as we'd wish for the same to be done for us.  The sooner society learns that every foolish action has consequences... the sooner society can move on from this stalemate!  --End Rant--

status_message:
Since we started this page, we have gotten a tremendous amount of support. We have been growing rapidly. We hope to continue to do so.
We cannot thank all of you enough for supporting us and our fellow LEOs around the country. We do this job for you. 
It is our goal to keep expanding and get as many followers as possible. 
This is a completely self funded page run by Police Officers for fellow officers and our supporters. All profits from the sales of our promotional shirts has gone directly back into funding the advertisement of this page so we can spread the message: Blue Lives Matter.

Again, thank you for following us and liking and sharing our content.

status_message:
Via one of our young followers, pretty powerful stuff:

I am just a boy
 A long way from being a man
 But let me speak for kids
 I hope you understand

You see we are the ones who hide
 The hurt that's in our heart
 When in our lives our Mom or Dad
 Miss all the important parts.

The baseball games and dances
 The programs and the like
 The first time we took a step
 Or learned to ride a bike.

The Holidays like Christmas
 Santa just isn.t the same
 when dad or mom aren't there
 To see the excitement you have
 That he came. 

But that is the easy part
 Of what our heart goes through
 The hard part comes when you understand
 The job your mom or dad has to do.

Can you imagine what it's like
 When you hit your needs to pray
 To have to ask God every time
 Bring dad or mom home safe today.

To see that fire truck carrying a casket
 Or the hearse in the long blue line
 And praying for those that lost
 Being thankful it wasn't our Mom or Dad's time

Seeing the hurt in Mom or Dad's eyes
 When they head out the door in harms way
 Saying I love ya and goodbye
 Knowing today could easily be their day.

As for me, through it all
 When all is said and done
 I wouldn't trade for nothing the honor
 Of being a Heroes Son.

You see my dad taught me honor
 To always hold my head up high
 To stand for what is right
 And that it's okay for big guys to cry.

To shake a mans hand like you mean it 
 Learn from your mistake
 Always try your best to keep 
 Each Promise that you make.

To love your God and Family 
 And love your Country too
 Pray and keep the Faith
 And God will see you through.

I will tell you this though
 If something happened to my dad today
 To the leaders of this city
 Hear me when I say

My Dad would die a Hero
 And his funeral is not a place you should be
 For I only want men of honor 
 Standing at that casket with me!!

 God Always Takes Care of Heroes Hide and Watch
 Hunter Pollard. Joshua 1:9

status_message:
This is unfortunate. We will refrain from judging these officers until their trial is completed. 
If you are a Law Enforcement Officer, remember this, integrity is all you have, it is all we have. When you tarnish it, your tarnish all of us. Think before you act.
The people we deal with are often the scum of the earth. Quick street justice is not the answer. Do your job right. Do it with honor. We will never catch them all. There will always be more of them than us. 
However, the country does not turn into one giant Baltimore because we exist. We serve a purpose. 
If you want to be a vigilante, go sew a costume, but don't relate yourself to us. Don't relate yourself to all of the officers who honor the oath they took. Your actions will effect all of us. We are under the microscope because of you. The public will never understand that Police have the lowest margin of error in business because your actions put us in spotlight of evil with the media.

status_message:
Here at Blue Lives Matter, we want to cover the gambit. We want to hit on the highs, the lows, and the controversial. It is our goal to bring awareness across the board. 

Some may be offended by the subjects that are posted, but you know what, that is the point. It is posted because of the content, you should be offended. We want you to know what is out there in this world we live in. We want you to be aware of the evil, the hate, and the ignorance. 

If something you see offends you, then we are doing our jobs correctly. It is not our goal to offend you ourselves but to have the subject matter that we post do the offending for us. 

Understand this, we know all lives matter, but we are here to stand up for what we believe, whether the world gets it or not, are the most oppressed individuals in our society today: Blue Lives. 

If you bleed blue, or someone close to you does, then we stand for you. You, your friends, your family, and even your enemies when they are in the right. We are not biased. Well, we are, but only to those who choose the path of evil. 

Have a great night.

status_message:
Why did you become the Police? Well, there are a lot of variables to that question. Yes, of course there is the excitement, the endorphin rush of driving code to the unknown, the thrill of the danger. However, whether we like to admit it or not, it is the altruistic nature ingrained in us that steers us towards this. calling. 
    The need to help others. The desire to save those who cannot help themselves. When the big picture of it all is examined, any one of us would take a bullet for a stranger. We would bend over backwards to get to the truth of the most miniscule of matters.
   Yes we have horrendous senses of humor, yes we make disgusting jokes about the heinous, but that is just our blanket of protection. In the end, we just want what is right, what is expected, what should be done. Sometimes the truth hurts, but we will always stand behind it.

status_message:
Officers observe a vehicle driving out of a parking lot, smoke coming out of the windows. The Officers, due to their training, knowledge, and experience, immediately recognize the odor currently slapping them in their nostrils like an angry woman to be that of marijuana. 

Yes, in liberal land, small amounts have become legal, but it is not legal to drive while high. So, said officers stop the vehicle. When they approach, they observe 3 male suspects inside. Before even being within 20ft of the vehicle, the angry woman smacks them again.

Once speaking with the passengers, they admit to marijuana being in the car. The Officers recover over 1 pound of neatly packaged marijuana ready for sale, paraphernalia, and a scale. 

Once back at the station, after advise of rights forms being signed and agreed upon, they admit to being on their happy way to sell the marijuana to a group of high school kids.

Case gets to the attorney's office. Attorney emails officer and says: "Hello officers, due to the recent climate surrounding marijuana, and that the odor was the only PC for the stop, we will not be going forward with this case."

WTF....Thoughts?

status_message:
Epic fail in progress in search for police chief in Bellevue, WA.
Fail 1: Final candidates are blaming police for Ferguson.
Fail 2: Cites an issue that that the city's population is now about 40 percent minority, while the police force is more than 80 percent white. This ignores the fact that the racial disparity comes from Bellevue being a hub for tech companies that attract a lot of highly skilled Asian employees. The minorities in the city are mostly affluent with the city's median household income is $104,839. Clearly we have another Ferguson in the making here. Good luck luring those minorities away from their six figure salary tech jobs.

status_message: Great training video. Watch as the officer uses a choke, people do not realize how almost unavoidable it is during a struggle. You grab for the largest exposed area which gives you purchase. More often than not, the head and neck area is what naturally works best. If your a certified street lawyer, please, try out this scenario for yourself and see how it works out for you. The individuals in this video have advanced training, far more than the average officer.

status_message:
A lot of us are not only dealing with the current media blitz against police in general, but a lot of us are also dealing with some pretty rough contract negotiations. Its not a great time for us now. Please continue to support your local police agencies in any way you can. 

For those that follow us that are police, don't give up, your not alone. This is hitting all of us hard across the country. Moral is at an all time low. To all you who are family and friends, support us. We will always be there for you.

link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
What makes a cop? The obvious? Is it the badge, the uniform, the gun, the training, the accumulation of knowledge and experience? Sure. All of that is part. However, without one specific thing, integrity, we are nothing but common, run of the mill citizens. Not that there is anything wrong with a common citizen, there is just no way they would ever be able to be a cop. 

It may sound like narcissism, but cops are truly a special breed. Not too many professions, aside from the military, come close to requiring the type of person it takes to be one of us. 

So, with all that said, don't screw it up for the rest of us. Hold yourselves to a higher standard. Keep your integrity solid. Be the cop you signed on to be. Make us (as in, all other cops) proud like we know you can.
Great gesture for a young hero.

status_message:
"And it's not just money that's at stake. The cameras may have other kinds of costs: They may affect police morale and recruitment."

Exactly...who really wants to be recorded all day long, in any job, for any reason? Think about it for a minute, how would you feel if the general consensus was that your field of work was not trusted, so the only way to keep your job was to be recorded at every moment to be used against you. We are not necessarily against it entirely but people seem to forget that we are people too, our privacy is valued just as much as the next persons.
link_name: Police Departments Issuing Body Cameras Discover Drawbacks

status_message: We are sure all of you have seen this by now, but if you haven't, it's worth watching. You will see first hand the stresses of dealing with an armed subject and how quickly things can go from calm to chaos. The end result is unfortunate for this individual, but there was no other outcome possible after he made a conscious decision to reach for his gun to fire at the officer. This officer did a phenomenal job. We hope he is doing well and that the stresses of this situation are not haunting him. He has nothing to feel bad about. He did his job absolutely perfectly.

status_message:
A police union is pushing to make it a federal hate crime to attack a law enforcement officer. Would this be a useless gesture, or a needed law?

If this happened, the law would likely follow other hate crime wording and state that the attack would have to be because the victim was a law enforcement officer. 99% of attacks on police are from suspects resisting arrest who are attacking to escape, and not because the victim is a law enforcement officer. Those are the attacks that too often don't get charged. 

The dirtbags who seek out law enforcement officers to attack often do so with a deadly intent, and in the unlikely situation that they survive, they will already face more severe prosecution locally than a 10 year federal sentence.

A new federal law could be useful to federally prosecute people who attack police while not armed with a deadly weapon, if the attack is just because of the uniform they wear. Is that currently a problem that needs a solution?
link_name: Police union pushes for cop killings to be included in federal hate crimes law

status_message:
There are so many things wrong with this: Officer who doesn't understand technology secretly recorded his interactions with suspects, co-workers, and supervisors in order to protect himself.
Fail:
1. He stored all recordings on the police department's servers, using up a quarter of their storage capacity.
2. Did not make the video known or available to defendants.
3. Knowing that he was recording, he still threatened to burn the department down and saved the video on police servers.

If you want to record, CYA and talk to your supervisors about it first.
link_name: Akron cop had 15 years of secret recordings
